Marital Quality and Self-Efficacy: Influence on Disease Management among Individuals with Rheumatoid Arthritis

Author: Tewary, Sweta; Farber, Naomi

Publication info: Journal of Evidence-Based Social Work  Vol. 11, Iss. 3,  (January 2014): 237-247.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1567044814?accountid=14667

Abstract: Individuals with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) struggle to maintain improved functional ability and reduced pain levels. Health education emphasizing self-efficacy helps individuals to adjust with the disease outcome and progression. As a basis to develop comprehensive evidence-based patient education programs, the aim of the study was to examine the role of marriage as a predictor of pain and functional self-efficacy among individuals with RA. Review of the regression analysis did not provide support for the relationships between marital quality and self-efficacy. Relationships were not observed between marital quality, length of marriage, and self-efficacy as predicted by the first hypothesis. Additional regression analysis examination found that marital quality, length of marriage, pain, and health assessment together reported significant variance in self-efficacy. However, only health assessment significantly predicted self-efficacy. Other nonexamined variables could have influenced the independent marital quality effects. Future longitudinal studies with larger sample sizes can further validate the current findings. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Marital+Quality+and+Self-Efficacy%3A+Influence+on+Disease+Management+among+Individuals+with+Rheumatoid+Arthritis&amp;rft.au=Tewary%2C+Sweta%3BFarber%2C+Naomi&amp;rft.aulast=Tewary&amp;rft.aufirst=Sweta&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=237&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15433714.2012.759458

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Marital+Quality+and+Self-Efficacy%3A+Influence+on+Disease+Management+among+Individuals+with+Rheumatoid+Arthritis&amp;rft.au=Tewary%2C+Sweta%3BFarber%2C+Naomi&amp;rft.aulast=Tewary&amp;rft.aufirst=Sweta&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=237&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15433714.2012.759458

Challenging Social Work Education's Urban Legends

Author: Colby, Ira

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education  Vol. 50, Iss. 2,  (0, 2014): 206-218.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1567044820?accountid=14667

Abstract: Urban legends circulate throughout society, including higher education and social work education. Some academic mythologies take on the status of a tradition-no matter the evidence or lack thereof-and continue to thrive, to influence thinking, and to shape norms, which, in turn, direct behaviors. As with urban legends, academic myths are able to overpower and dismiss the conclusions drawn from critical thinking processes. Accreditation standards, common program structures, and faculty behaviors and expectations have evolved over time grounded in and shaped by various legends. Social work educators applying critical thinking processes to their educational enterprise will be able to challenge with intellectual rigor the profession's urban legends, which will then result in national standards and program models that are creative, proactive, and forward-thinking. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Challenging+Social+Work+Education%27s+Urban+Legends&amp;rft.au=Colby%2C+Ira&amp;rft.aulast=Colby&amp;rft.aufirst=Ira&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=206&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Work and Medical Care: Electronic Reminders to Address Adherence

Author: Whisenhunt, Allison

Publication info: Journal of Evidence-Based Social Work  Vol. 11, Iss. 3,  (January 2014): 248-255.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1567044826?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social workers are often involved with patients and families around adherence, both to clinic appointments as well as to the medication regimen. An evidence-based practice project was created and implemented to determine the efficacy of electronic reminders such as text messaging on adherence. The implications of improving adherence can positively impact the patient on an individual level as well as reduce costs and increase revenue at a systems level. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+and+Medical+Care%3A+Electronic+Reminders+to+Address+Adherence&amp;rft.au=Whisenhunt%2C+Allison&amp;rft.aulast=Whisenhunt&amp;rft.aufirst=Allison&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=248&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15433714.2012.759460

Implementation Frameworks and MSW Curricula: Encouraging Pursuit and Use of Model Pertinent Data

Author: Bertram, Rosalyn M; King, Kelli; Pederson, Rachel; Nutt, Justin

Publication info: Journal of Evidence-Based Social Work  Vol. 11, Iss. 1-2,  (January 2014): 193-207.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1567046074?accountid=14667

Abstract: Graduate preparation of social workers and the infrastructure of service delivery too often limit the pursuit and use of data to inform practice. We review literature addressing student and practitioner motivation and interests, as well as masters-level social work curriculum content. This establishes a context for presentation of Masters in Social Work (MSW) student evaluations of program implementation at 34 field placement sites throughout the greater Kansas City region. Their evaluations focus through frameworks identified by the National Implementation Research Network to examine patterns of implementation and program data usage. Based on student lessons learned, we suggest MSW curricula revision to foster student and program appreciation and use of data. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Implementation+Frameworks+and+MSW+Curricula%3A+Encouraging+Pursuit+and+Use+of+Model+Pertinent+Data&amp;rft.au=Bertram%2C+Rosalyn+M%3BKing%2C+Kelli%3BPederson%2C+Rachel%3BNutt%2C+Justin&amp;rft.aulast=Bertram&amp;rft.aufirst=Rosalyn&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=193&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15433714.2013.850324

Political and Medical Views on Medical Marijuana and its Future

Author: Rubens, Muni11 Department of Health Promotion and Disease Prevention, Florida International University, 11200 SW 8th Street, Miami, FL 33199, USA mrube001@fiu.edu

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 29, Iss. 1-2,  (0, 2014): 121-131.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1622293114?accountid=14667

Abstract: The policies, laws, politics, public opinions, and scientific inferences of medical marijuana are rapidly changing as the debate on medical use of marijuana has always been political, rather than scientific. Federal law has barred the use of medical marijuana though 18 state governments and Washington, DC, support the medical use of marijuana. Unfortunately, not many studies exist on medical marijuana to back these laws and policies. The judiciary, on the other hand, has elicited a diverse response to medical marijuana through its rulings over several decades. Some rulings favored the federal government's opinion, and others supported the larger public view and many state governments with legalized medical marijuana. Public opinion on legalizing medical marijuana has always favored the use of medical marijuana. The movement of scientific knowledge of medical marijuana follows an erratic, discontinuous pathway. The future place of medical marijuana in U.S. society remains unknown. The three forces-scientific knowledge, social-political acceptance, and laws-play a role in the direction that medical marijuana takes in society. Overcoming political-social forces requires a concerted effort from the scientific community and political leaders. The results of scientific research must guide the decisions for laws and medical use of marijuana. This article aims to trace the political dilemma and contradictory views shared by federal and state governments and predict the future of medical marijuana by tracing the past history of medical marijuana with its bumpy pathway in the social-political arena. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Political+and+Medical+Views+on+Medical+Marijuana+and+its+Future&amp;rft.au=Rubens%2C+Muni&amp;rft.aulast=Rubens&amp;rft.aufirst=Muni&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=121&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2013.821351

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Political+and+Medical+Views+on+Medical+Marijuana+and+its+Future&amp;rft.au=Rubens%2C+Muni&amp;rft.aulast=Rubens&amp;rft.aufirst=Muni&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=121&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2013.821351

Exclusionary Health Policy: Responding to the Risk of Poor Health among Sexual Minority Youth in Canada

Author: Ylioja, Thomas1; Craig, Shelley L1 Factor-Inwentash Faculty of Social Work, University of Toronto, Toronto, Ontario, Canada Thomas_ylioja@hotmail.com

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 29, Iss. 1-2,  (0, 2014): 81-86.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1622293228?accountid=14667

Abstract: Measuring indicators of health status and demographics are essential in the population health approach. In Canada, sexual minority youth face increased risk for poor health outcomes in behavioral and mental health indicators, yet the health policy response has been severely lacking. The current population health approach exacerbates the social exclusion of a vulnerable, at-risk population. The authors examine health status through the social determinants of health to highlight the need for including sexual identity, attraction, and behavior in youth population health surveys. Additional interventions that address the social determinants of health are needed. Adapted from the source document.

Associations between Birth Health, Maternal Employment, and Child Care Arrangement among a Community Sample of Mothers with Young Children

Author: Chiao, Chi1; Chyu, Laura; Ksobiech, Kate1 Institute of Health and Welfare Policy and Research Center for Health and Welfare Policy, College of Medicine, National Yang-Ming University, Taipei, Taiwan cchiao@ym.edu.tw

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 29, Iss. 1-2,  (0, 2014): 42-53.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1622293284?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although a large body of literature exists on how different types of child care arrangements affect a child's subsequent health and sociocognitive development, little is known about the relationship between birth health and subsequent decisions regarding type of nonparental child care as well as how this relationship might be influenced by maternal employment. This study used data from the Los Angeles Families and Neighborhoods Survey (L.A.FANS). Mothers of 864 children (ages 0-5) provided information regarding birth weight, maternal evaluation of a child's birth health, child's current health, maternal employment, type of child care arrangement chosen, and a variety of socioeconomic variables. Child care options included parental care, relative care, nonrelative care, and daycare center. Multivariate analyses found that birth weight and subjective rating of birth health had similar effects on child care arrangement. After controlling for a child's age and current health condition, multinomial logit analyses found that mothers with children with poorer birth health are more likely to use nonrelative and daycare centers than parental care when compared to mothers with children with better birth health. The magnitude of these relationships diminished when adjusting for maternal employment. Working mothers were significantly more likely to use nonparental child care than nonemployed mothers. Results suggest that a child's health early in life is significantly but indirectly related to subsequent decisions regarding child care arrangements, and this association is influenced by maternal employment. Development of social policy aimed at improving child care service should take maternal and family backgrounds into consideration. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Associations+between+Birth+Health%2C+Maternal+Employment%2C+and+Child+Care+Arrangement+among+a+Community+Sample+of+Mothers+with+Young+Children&amp;rft.au=Chiao%2C+Chi%3BChyu%2C+Laura%3BKsobiech%2C+Kate&amp;rft.aulast=Chiao&amp;rft.aufirst=Chi&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=42&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2011.619465

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Associations+between+Birth+Health%2C+Maternal+Employment%2C+and+Child+Care+Arrangement+among+a+Community+Sample+of+Mothers+with+Young+Children&amp;rft.au=Chiao%2C+Chi%3BChyu%2C+Laura%3BKsobiech%2C+Kate&amp;rft.aulast=Chiao&amp;rft.aufirst=Chi&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=42&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2011.619465

Effective Doctor-Patient Communication: An Updated Examination

Author: Matusitz, Jonathan1; Spear, Jennifer1 Nicholson School of Communication, University of Central Florida, Orlando, Florida, USA; University of Central Florida at Seminole State College, Partnership Center (#UP 3009), 100 Weldon Hlvd., Orlando, FL 32773, USA matusitz@gmail.com

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 29, Iss. 3-4,  (0, 2014): 252-266.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142070?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article examines, in detail, the quality of doctor-patient interaction. Doctor-patient communication is such a powerful indicator of health care quality that it can determine patients' self-management behavior and health outcomes. The medical visit (i.e., the medical encounter) plays a pivotal role in the health care process. In fact, doctor-patient communication is one of the most essential dynamics in health care, affecting the course of patient care and patient compliance with recommendations for care. Unlike many other analyses (that often look at only one or two specific aspects of doctor-patient relationships), this analysis is more encompassing; it looks at doctor-patient communication from multiple perspectives. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Effective+Doctor-Patient+Communication%3A+An+Updated+Examination&amp;rft.au=Matusitz%2C+Jonathan%3BSpear%2C+Jennifer&amp;rft.aulast=Matusitz&amp;rft.aufirst=Jonathan&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=252&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2013.776416

The Integrated Behavioral Health Service Delivery System Model

Author: Wodarski, John S11 College of Social Work, The University of Tennessee, Knoxville, 324 Henson Hall, Knoxville, TN 37996, USA jwodarsk@utk.edu

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 29, Iss. 3-4,  (0, 2014): 301-317.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142193?accountid=14667

Abstract: Costs and effective management of health care in general, and behavioral health care in particular, have been of primary importance and concern to federal, state, and local governments. With the passage of Health Care Reform (HCR) these concerns will only escalate. Thus, the necessity for the development of innovative, successful, and integrated cost-effective treatments and procedures is evident. The behavioral health care model presented here is proposed to address these needs. The model centers on the composition of effective psychosocial treatment and provides a cost analysis of social work and its services. By defining the problems that need to be addressed in health care management and cost containment, and applying findings of evidence-based studies, this article provides an effective model for health care organizations. It also presents a profile of the behavioral health social worker, defining the requisite abilities for effectiveness in the role and looking at the key impact areas for a behavioral health model. This comprehensive guide will prepare new social workers entering health care organizations as well as provide a valuable reference for existing social workers, academics, and practitioners of behavioral health care. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=The+Integrated+Behavioral+Health+Service+Delivery+System+Model&amp;rft.au=Wodarski%2C+John+S&amp;rft.aulast=Wodarski&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=301&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2011.622243

An Exploration of Women Offenders' Health Literacy

Author: Donelle, Lone1; Hall, Jodi1 Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Western Ontario, Room H28, Health Sciences Addition, London, Ontario N6A 5C1 Canada ldonelle@uwo.ca

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 29, Iss. 3-4,  (0, 2014): 240-251.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142220?accountid=14667

Abstract: In the past decade the sentencing of women in Canada to correctional detention has increased. Compared to the general population, women in conflict with the law tend to have higher rates of mortality and morbidity. This exploratory research investigated health promotion and health- literacy issues for women offenders. Semistructured interviews of 12 women serving probation orders were analyzed. Data analysis highlighted three overarching themes: (a) health information access, (b) networks of support, and (c) tailoring the health system. These findings have relevancy for health promotion practice with women offenders, and implications for correctional services community reintegration programs and community health sectors. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=An+Exploration+of+Women+Offenders%27+Health+Literacy&amp;rft.au=Donelle%2C+Lone%3BHall%2C+Jodi&amp;rft.aulast=Donelle&amp;rft.aufirst=Lone&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=240&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.20+13.776415

Ryan White CARE Act Part D: Matches and Gaps in Political Commitment and Local Implementation

Author: Hernandez, Julieta P1; Potocky, Miriam1 School of Social Work, Florida International University, Miami, Florida, USA; University of Miami, Miller School of Medicine, Pediatrics, Mailman Center for Child Development, 1601 NW 12 Ave., Room 4055 (D-820), Miami, FL 33136, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 29, Iss. 3-4,  (0, 2014): 267-284.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142303?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article demonstrates the opportunities for and challenges of the Ryan White Comprehensive AIDS Resources Emergency (CARE) Act Part D to implementing its mandate for comprehensive family-centered systems of care for women, infants, children, and youth with HIV/AIDS. Part D legislation should promote practices addressing families with models for basic security, judiciously embrace those universal public health policies aiming to improve children's overall welfare, and consistently repudiate those policies infringing on human rights of women infected with HIV, or ignoring their children's basic needs. The proposed revisions to Part D implementation may renew its political commitment to serving the needs of families who are HIV affected. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

School-Based Vaccination Programs and the HPV Vaccine in 16 Appalachian Kentucky School Districts: Results from a Pilot Study

Author: Ely, Gretchen E1; Fields, Morgan; Dignan, Mark1 College of Social Work, University of Kentucky, Lexington, Kentucky, USA; University of Kentucky, College of Social Work, 639 Patterson Office Tower, Lexington, KY 40506, USA gretchen.ely@uky.edu

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 29, Iss. 3-4,  (0, 2014): 368-379.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650143551?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this article is to describe a pilot study of 16 Appalachian Kentucky school districts designed to gather information about their school vaccination and health education programs in relation to the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine. School district administrators were contacted by a professional telephone interviewer and asked to participate in a structured interview that also included open-ended questions. Results suggest that few schools have school-based vaccination programs, and of those that do, very few programs include the HPV vaccine. A majority of respondents reported that information leaflets about HPV are available in the schools, whereas few schools include discussions of HPV in their health programs. Almost all respondents reported an excellent relationship with their county health departments, school nurses, and school social workers, although most schools lacked the presence of a school social worker. Implications for social work practice and policy and directions for future research are also discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Community-Led Total Sanitation: A 'New Frontier' for International Social Work Practice

Author: Wolfer, Terry A11 College of Social Work, University of South Carolina terry.wolfer@sc.edu

Publication info: Social Development Issues  Vol. 36, Iss. 1,  (0, 2014): 67-77.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018461?accountid=14667

Abstract: Currently, some 2.5 billion people lack adequate sanitation, including 1 billion who practice open defecation. Because inadequate sanitation is both a cause and effect of extreme poverty, it deserves inclusion on the international social work agenda. This article introduces community-led total sanitation (CLTS), a recent and highly effective innovation for mobilizing whole communities to address their sanitation problems. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Development+Issues&amp;rft.atitle=Community-Led+Total+Sanitation%3A+A+%27New+Frontier%27+for+International+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=Wolfer%2C+Terry+A&amp;rft.aulast=Wolfer&amp;rft.aufirst=Terry&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=36&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=67&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Development+Issues&amp;rft.issn=01471473&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Constitutionalism and Social Development in Kenya

Author: Okech, David1; Ottenweller, Matthew; Elkins, Jennifer; Caldwell, Elliot; Segoshi, Megan1 School of Social Work, University of Georgia dokech@uga.edu

Publication info: Social Development Issues  Vol. 36, Iss. 1,  (0, 2014): 78-92.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018515?accountid=14667

Abstract: New constitutions can be critical transformational tools for enhancing the welfare of marginalized populations in a country. This article discusses the opportunities and challenges that Kenya is likely to face as it transforms itself in the new constitutional dispensation. We pay specific attention to comparing how Kenya's new constitution protects the rights of vulnerable citizens. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Development+Issues&amp;rft.atitle=Constitutionalism+and+Social+Development+in+Kenya&amp;rft.au=Okech%2C+David%3BOttenweller%2C+Matthew%3BElkins%2C+Jennifer%3BCaldwell%2C+Elliot%3BSegoshi%2C+Megan&amp;rft.aulast=Okech&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=36&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=78&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Development+Issues&amp;rft.issn=01471473&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Posttraumatic Stress among Youths in Juvenile Detention

Author: Falk, Derek; Thompson, Sanna J; Sanford, Julia

Publication info: Journal of Evidence-Based Social Work  Vol. 11, Iss. 4,  (January 2014): 383-391.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018544?accountid=14667

Abstract: An estimated 1.8 million juveniles were arrested in the United States for delinquency in 2009. Previous studies indicate high rates of exposure to traumatic events and posttraumatic stress (PTS) symptoms for these youths. This study examined PTS in a sample of 170 youths in juvenile detention. The results of this study reveal higher rates of PTS symptoms (21%) compared to national rates (6%). The data also suggest youths suffering from more PTS symptoms also report higher depression, anxiety, anger, family relationship worries, thought problems, and attention problems. These factors provide a direction for continued practice targeting these youths. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Posttraumatic+Stress+among+Youths+in+Juvenile+Detention&amp;rft.au=Falk%2C+Derek%3BThompson%2C+Sanna+J%3BSanford%2C+Julia&amp;rft.aulast=Falk&amp;rft.aufirst=Derek&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=383&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2014.897111

Schools as Pillars of Postwar Recovery: Rethinking the Role of Parental Involvement

Author: Sugawara, Carmen Geanina Luca1; Delale, Eva Andela; Hermoso, Jocelyn Clare R; Barrett, Diana1 School of Social Work, Indiana University

Publication info: Social Development Issues  Vol. 36, Iss. 1,  (0, 2014): 17-32.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018610?accountid=14667

Abstract: The promotion of parental involvement as a community reconstruction strategy after interethnic war is relatively new and lacks empirical support. This article explores the role of parental involvement in community reconstruction in postwar Croatia. Results show that parental involvement in schools can contribute to the rebuilding of a community's social capital, which is an important step in recovering from interethnic war. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Development+Issues&amp;rft.atitle=Schools+as+Pillars+of+Postwar+Recovery%3A+Rethinking+the+Role+of+Parental+Involvement&amp;rft.au=Sugawara%2C+Carmen+Geanina+Luca%3BDelale%2C+Eva+Andela%3BHermoso%2C+Jocelyn+Clare+R%3BBarrett%2C+Diana&amp;rft.aulast=Sugawara&amp;rft.aufirst=Carmen+Geanina&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=36&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=17&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Development+Issues&amp;rft.issn=01471473&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Effects of Occupation, Public Assistance, Prejudice, and Disadvantaged Neighborhood on Second- and Third-Generation Immigrants Downward Assimilation

Author: Jaggers, Jeremiah1; Cheng, Tyrone1 East Tennessee State University jaggers@etsu.edu

Publication info: Social Development Issues  Vol. 36, Iss. 1,  (0, 2014): 1-16.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018718?accountid=14667

Abstract: We conducted an analysis of data describing 2,522 second- and third-generation immigrants, exploring how downward assimilation might be associated with labor union membership, occupational skills, residence in a disadvantaged neighborhood, and prejudice. The sample was extracted from the Immigration and Intergenerational Metropolitan Los Angeles 2004 data set. Multiple regression results showed that union membership and occupational skills have a negative association with downward assimilation. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Development+Issues&amp;rft.atitle=The+Effects+of+Occupation%2C+Public+Assistance%2C+Prejudice%2C+and+Disadvantaged+Neighborhood+on+Second-+and+Third-Generation+Immigrants+Downward+Assimilation&amp;rft.au=Jaggers%2C+Jeremiah%3BCheng%2C+Tyrone&amp;rft.aulast=Jaggers&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeremiah&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=36&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Development+Issues&amp;rft.issn=01471473&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Is Work-Family Enrichment an Antidote to Experiences of Psychological Strain Among Australian Social Workers? An Empirical Study

Author: Kalliath, Parveen

Publication info: Australian Social Work  Vol. 67, Iss. 3,  (January 2014): 332-347.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018910?accountid=14667

Abstract: Few studies in work-family interface have explored the work-family experiences of social workers as an occupational group. Further, work-family conflict and its impact on psychological strain have dominated the majority of the literature. The positive effects of participation in work and family roles remain under-researched despite consensus among scholars confirming the benefits of participation in both roles. The present study contributes significantly to the gap in the literature by examining the work-family enrichment experiences of Australian social workers and its association with psychological strain. Data for the study were collected via online survey of the membership of the Australian Association of Social Workers and included one open-ended question asking social workers to comment on their work-family enrichment experiences. The survey yielded a usable sample of 439 responses. Hierarchical multiple regression analyses were conducted to examine the direct effects of the three forms of work-to-family enrichment (WFE) and family-to-work enrichment (FWE) on psychological strain. The results showed that WFE-Affect, WFE-Capital, and FWE-Affect were significantly associated with reduced psychological strain. The qualitative findings provided further evidence of the benefits associated with participation in work and family roles. The implications of the findings for theory, practice and service provision are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Is+Work-Family+Enrichment+an+Antidote+to+Experiences+of+Psychological+Strain+Among+Australian+Social+Workers%3F+An+Empirical+Study&amp;rft.au=Kalliath%2C+Parveen&amp;rft.aulast=Kalliath&amp;rft.aufirst=Parveen&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=67&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=332&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=0312407X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0312407X.2013.825302

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Is+Work-Family+Enrichment+an+Antidote+to+Experiences+of+Psychological+Strain+Among+Australian+Social+Workers%3F+An+Empirical+Study&amp;rft.au=Kalliath%2C+Parveen&amp;rft.aulast=Kalliath&amp;rft.aufirst=Parveen&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=67&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=332&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=0312407X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0312407X.2013.825302

Subject: Social Workers; Australia; Participation; Family Work Relationship; Occupational Roles; Family Roles; Membership; Emotional Abuse; Internet

Classification: 6150: professional issues in social work

Identifier / keyword: Work-to-family Enrichment Family-to-work Enrichment Social Workers Psychological Strain

Title: Is Work-Family Enrichment an Antidote to Experiences of Psychological Strain Among Australian Social Workers? An Empirical Study

Correspondence author: Kalliath, Parveen  

Publication title: Australian Social Work

Volume: 67

Issue: 3

Pages: 332-347

Number of pages: 16

Publication year: 2014

Publisher: Routledge Journals, Taylor & Francis, Oxfordshire UK

ISSN: 0312-407X

Source type: Scholarly Journals

Peer reviewed: Yes

Language of publication: English

Using Friendship to Build Professional Family Work Relationships where Child Neglect is an Issue: Worker Perceptions

Author: Reimer, Elizabeth Claire

Publication info: Australian Social Work  Vol. 67, Iss. 3,  (January 2014): 315-331.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660019907?accountid=14667

Abstract: Effective working relationships are those which are characterised by close personal contact, even friendship-like in nature, contained within professional boundaries. However, such personal ways of working remain a contentious aspect of professional relationships. Indeed, workers operating in this way commonly experience disapproval from colleagues. Guidance regarding how workers build personalised professional relationships while operating in a disapproving environment is limited. This is even more pronounced for building relationships with families where child neglect is an issue. This paper draws on a study of perceptions of eight parent-family worker relationship cases in New South Wales, Australia. The study utilised qualitative research methods to analyse and compare participants' perceptions of the experiences and meaning of working relationships with families where child neglect is an issue. The paper will explore how the workers' use of friendship-like characteristics to build highly personalised, yet professional and ethical, relationships created discord with some colleagues, including accusations of unprofessional and unethical practice. Drawing on these workers' experiences, along with literature that challenges traditional ways of working with clients, it will be argued that dominant ideas about ethical and professional practice hinder the development of effective relationships with clients, create unnecessary stress for workers, and should be challenged. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Using+Friendship+to+Build+Professional+Family+Work+Relationships+where+Child+Neglect+is+an+Issue%3A+Worker+Perceptions&amp;rft.au=Reimer%2C+Elizabeth+Claire&amp;rft.aulast=Reimer&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=67&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=315&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=0312407X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0312407X.2013.815240

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Using+Friendship+to+Build+Professional+Family+Work+Relationships+where+Child+Neglect+is+an+Issue%3A+Worker+Perceptions&amp;rft.au=Reimer%2C+Elizabeth+Claire&amp;rft.aulast=Reimer&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=67&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=315&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=0312407X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0312407X.2013.815240

Individual Economic Well-Being and the Development of Bridging and Bonding Social Capital

Author: Zhang, Saijun1; Anderson, Steve1 Children and Family Research Center, School of Social Work, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign szhang11@illinois.edu

Publication info: Social Development Issues  Vol. 36, Iss. 1,  (0, 2014): 33-51.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660019938?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study distinguishes bonding and bridging social capital, and it uses a nationally representative data set to examine the role of individual economic well-being on the development of bonding and bridging social capital. Multivariate analyses suggest that individual economic well-being is positively associated with the development of bridging capital but not with any type of measured bonding capital. Policy and practice implications regarding the findings are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Development+Issues&amp;rft.atitle=Individual+Economic+Well-Being+and+the+Development+of+Bridging+and+Bonding+Social+Capital&amp;rft.au=Zhang%2C+Saijun%3BAnderson%2C+Steve&amp;rft.aulast=Zhang&amp;rft.aufirst=Saijun&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=36&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=33&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Development+Issues&amp;rft.issn=01471473&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Development+Issues&amp;rft.atitle=Individual+Economic+Well-Being+and+the+Development+of+Bridging+and+Bonding+Social+Capital&amp;rft.au=Zhang%2C+Saijun%3BAnderson%2C+Steve&amp;rft.aulast=Zhang&amp;rft.aufirst=Saijun&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=36&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=33&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Development+Issues&amp;rft.issn=01471473&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Sexual Assault in Relationships: Seeking Help on a Q&A Website

Author: Webber, Ruth

Publication info: Australian Social Work  Vol. 67, Iss. 3,  (January 2014): 363-376.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660019980?accountid=14667

Abstract: Young people are increasingly turning to question-and-answer online environments such as Yahoo! Answers for advice. This paper reports on a qualitative investigation of the content and meaning behind 30 questions and 212 answers posted on Yahoo! Answers (2005-11) about incidents of sexual assault within a dating relationship or between school 'friends'. A comparison was made between the responses of sexual assault counsellors and other members. Interpretive description methodology was used in the analysis. Relationship status, time since the abuse, and age influenced the extent to which Askers were able to name the incident as abuse. The answers provided by counsellors typically included a supportive comment, advice (personal, legal, and medical), reflection or interpretation, resources, and places to go for help. Other members' answers lacked consistency, often failing to provide appropriate advice, empathy, and resources. Counselling organisations could consider providing online services for people who are seeking help for sexual assault. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Sexual+Assault+in+Relationships%3A+Seeking+Help+on+a+Q%26amp%3BA+Website&amp;rft.au=Webber%2C+Ruth&amp;rft.aulast=Webber&amp;rft.aufirst=Ruth&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=67&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=363&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=0312407X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0312407X.2013.834065

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Sexual+Assault+in+Relationships%3A+Seeking+Help+on+a+Q%26amp%3BA+Website&amp;rft.au=Webber%2C+Ruth&amp;rft.aulast=Webber&amp;rft.aufirst=Ruth&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=67&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=363&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=0312407X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0312407X.2013.834065

The Parent Empowerment and Efficacy Measure (PEEM): A Tool for Strengthening the Accountability and Effectiveness of Family Support Services

Author: Freiberg, Kate; Homel, Ross; Branch, Sara

Publication info: Australian Social Work  Vol. 67, Iss. 3,  (January 2014): 405-418.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660019994?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes the development, validity, and reliability of the Parent Empowerment and Efficacy Measure (PEEM). Development was guided by theory and by challenges faced by Pathways to Prevention family support staff who required a short, practical, and reliable measure of parent empowerment. The measure's psychometric properties were tested using data from 866 parents of children aged 5 to 12, living in high to low socioeconomic status areas. Principal factor analysis revealed a strong general dimension with high internal consistency (a = 0.92) that correlated at 0.60 or more with three validation measures, as well as the existence of two hypothesised subfactors (correlated at 0.78): efficacy to parent and efficacy to connect, each with internal consistencies of 0.85+. Test-retest reliability (n = 200) was 0.84. PEEM exhibits excellent convergent and concurrent validity and is a reliable tool for use in planning services, monitoring participant progress, and evaluating program effectiveness. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Parent+Empowerment+and+Efficacy+Measure+%28PEEM%29%3A+A+Tool+for+Strengthening+the+Accountability+and+Effectiveness+of+Family+Support+Services&amp;rft.au=Freiberg%2C+Kate%3BHomel%2C+Ross%3BBranch%2C+Sara&amp;rft.aulast=Freiberg&amp;rft.aufirst=Kate&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=67&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=405&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=0312407X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0312407X.2014.902980

Social Work Education in Saudi Arabia: A Review

Author: Albrithen, Abdulaziz11 Department of Social Studies, King Saud University, Saudi Arabia aziz88@hotmail.co.uk

Publication info: Social Development Issues  Vol. 36, Iss. 1,  (0, 2014): 52-66.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660020270?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work education is an essential part and indeed a foundation of the social work profession. As a fast-developing country, Saudi Arabia has been witnessing many changes that require a suitable response from social work professionals as well as social work educators. This article surveys the current state of social work education in Saudi Arabia, revealing some negative points and highlighting suggestions for improvement. Adapted from the source document.

Defining Signature Pedagogy in Social Work Education: Learning Theory and the Learning Contract

Author: Boitel, Craig R; Fromm, Laurentine R

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education  Vol. 50, Iss. 4,  (0, 2014): 608.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947265?accountid=14667

Abstract: In 2008, the Council on Social Work Education identified field education as the signature pedagogy of social work. In doing so, it designated field education as the synthetic, integrative curricular area in which students are socialized to the profession. This article examines challenges and opportunities this designation presents. How field education can be designed and delivered as social work education's signature pedagogy is discussed from a learning theory framework. A learning contract is described that integrates class and field in attainment of the core and advanced competencies. Use of this integrated learning contract by the field instructor and student serves to structure the field experience in a manner consistent with a signature pedagogy. The teaching role of the field instructor is recognized as a key component of the signature pedagogy. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Defining+Signature+Pedagogy+in+Social+Work+Education%3A+Learning+Theory+and+the+Learning+Contract&amp;rft.au=Boitel%2C+Craig+R%3BFromm%2C+Laurentine+R&amp;rft.aulast=Boitel&amp;rft.aufirst=Craig&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=608&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Teaching Note-Radically Rethinking the Foundation

Author: Robbins, Susan P

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education  Vol. 50, Iss. 4,  (0, 2014): 740.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947711?accountid=14667

Abstract: This teaching note presents an innovative model by which a 1-semester hybrid master of social work foundation can be delivered and delineates the structural, content, and process elements that make it unique. It also discusses the use of collaborative planning and teaching that is necessary to implement this model, as well as the role of continuous assessment in evaluating the process and outcomes and improving the educational experience for students. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Teaching+Note-Radically+Rethinking+the+Foundation&amp;rft.au=Robbins%2C+Susan+P&amp;rft.aulast=Robbins&amp;rft.aufirst=Susan&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=740&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Implicit Curriculum in an Urban University Setting: Pathways to Students' Empowerment

Author: Peterson, N Andrew; Farmer, Antoinette Y; Zippay, Allison

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education  Vol. 50, Iss. 4,  (0, 2014): 630.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947950?accountid=14667

Abstract: Professional schools are developing conceptual frameworks that can be used to assess and improve an implicit curricula. Students' professional empowerment, defined to include perceived professional competence and identity, may be considered a vital outcome of these efforts. The study evaluated measures and tested a path model that included perceptions of characteristics of implicit curricula (i.e., faculty and staff diversity, supportive faculty, opportunity role structure, and access to information) and mediating variables (i.e., participation, sense of community, and feeling valued by the school) as predictors of professional empowerment. Respondents were students (N = 423) of a school of social work in the northeast. Results supported the validity of the scales and fit of the hypothesized model. Implications and directions for future research are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=The+Implicit+Curriculum+in+an+Urban+University+Setting%3A+Pathways+to+Students%27+Empowerment&amp;rft.au=Peterson%2C+N+Andrew%3BFarmer%2C+Antoinette+Y%3BZippay%2C+Allison&amp;rft.aulast=Peterson&amp;rft.aufirst=N&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=630&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Bachelor of Social Work Students and Mental Health Stigma: Understanding Student Attitudes

Author: Zellmann, Karen T; Madden, Elissa E; Aguiniga, Donna M

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education  Vol. 50, Iss. 4,  (0, 2014): 660.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667948068?accountid=14667

Abstract: Bachelor-level social work students at a midsized Midwestern public university were surveyed to evaluate their attitudes toward those with mental health concerns. Additionally, students were surveyed regarding their willingness to seek treatment for their own mental health needs. Results of the analyses suggest that the majority of students do not hold stigmatizing attitudes toward mental illness. Students who believed mental health work is rewarding, were less likely to be afraid or uncomfortable around people with mental illness. In addition, these students were more likely to report attitudes that acknowledge the capabilities of people with mental illness and were less concerned with others knowing their own mental health status. Implications for social work education and directions for future research are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Bachelor+of+Social+Work+Students+and+Mental+Health+Stigma%3A+Understanding+Student+Attitudes&amp;rft.au=Zellmann%2C+Karen+T%3BMadden%2C+Elissa+E%3BAguiniga%2C+Donna+M&amp;rft.aulast=Zellmann&amp;rft.aufirst=Karen&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=660&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Social Work: A Profession in Search of Its Identity

Author: Gitterman, Alex

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education  Vol. 50, Iss. 4,  (0, 2014): 599.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667948270?accountid=14667

Abstract: Micro social work practice can be understood in the context of its historical professional traditions and dialectics as well as the environmental pressures and demands placed on the profession. In becoming a profession, social work relied heavily on principles drawn from medicine and science. Although these bodies of knowledge provided the profession certain credibility, their application may have clouded social work's distinctive social purpose and professional identity. In its search for a distinctive function and identity, the profession of social work has struggled with numerous dialectics, as discussed in this article. These help the researchers to better understand the profession's search for its distinctive identity and status and the importance of including this content in social work education. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work%3A+A+Profession+in+Search+of+Its+Identity&amp;rft.au=Gitterman%2C+Alex&amp;rft.aulast=Gitterman&amp;rft.aufirst=Alex&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=599&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Sibling Resentments and Alliances during the Parent Care Years: Implications for Social Work Practice

Author: Lashewicz, Bonnie

Publication info: Journal of Evidence-Based Social Work  Vol. 11, Iss. 5,  (January 2014): 460-467.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1680148946?accountid=14667

Abstract: Do many hands make lighter work for siblings caring for aging parents? Anchored in theoretical concepts of filial responsibility and equity, this article is an in-depth examination of tensions between caregiving siblings in two families. This article contributes understandings about ways siblings may differ in their views of parent care and how resentments arising from these differences incline siblings to seek support by aligning with one or more other siblings. The purpose of this examination is to illuminate complex sibling relationships that can impact parent care, and to provoke reflection on social work practices for navigating difficult sibling relationships and promoting high quality care for aging parents. Questions are raised for social workers who may find themselves at the center of competing instructions from siblings who are each proclaiming dedication to 'what's best for mom.'. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Sibling+Resentments+and+Alliances+during+the+Parent+Care+Years%3A+Implications+for+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=Lashewicz%2C+Bonnie&amp;rft.aulast=Lashewicz&amp;rft.aufirst=Bonnie&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=460&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15433714.2013.764834

Improving the Archiving of Records in the Out-of-home Care Sector

Author: Humphreys, Cathy; McCarthy, Gavan; Dowling, Melissa; Kertesz, Margaret; Tropea, Rachel

Publication info: Australian Social Work  Vol. 67, Iss. 4,  (January 2014): 509-524.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1680148954?accountid=14667

Abstract: Senate Inquiries into the lives of people who grew up in care, highly critical Ombudsman reports, and advocacy groups for recent and past 'care leavers' draw attention to the significance of the records for children growing up in out-of-home care. This article reports on a project in which an interdisciplinary team of social workers, archivists, and historians worked together with 12 community-sector (nongovernment) organisations to look at the question of how to improve the management of the records for people with experience of out-of-home care. A Self Assessment Tool was developed and deployed at two points in time to provide feedback to organisations about the quality of their record-keeping practices. Clear improvements could be documented over a 2-year period in all 12 of the organisations involved. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Improving+the+Archiving+of+Records+in+the+Out-of-home+Care+Sector&amp;rft.au=Humphreys%2C+Cathy%3BMcCarthy%2C+Gavan%3BDowling%2C+Melissa%3BKertesz%2C+Margaret%3BTropea%2C+Rachel&amp;rft.aulast=Humphreys&amp;rft.aufirst=Cathy&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=67&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=509&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=0312407X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0312407X.2013.856453

Values Important to Terminally Ill African American Older Adults in Receiving Hospice Care

Author: Noh, Hyunjin

Publication info: Journal of Social Work in End-of-Life & Palliative Care  Vol. 10, Iss. 4,  (January 2014): 338-355.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1680148993?accountid=14667

Abstract: While racial disparity in the use of hospice care by older African Americans is widely acknowledged, little is known about the values that they consider as important in receiving health care services along with direct experiences with having these values respected by hospice care providers. Using individual, face-to-face interviews, data were collected directly from 28 African American hospice patients about their experiences in hospice care. Content analysis was used to identify and categorize themes from multiple readings of the qualitative data. Resulting themes included: dying at home, open communications, independent decision-making, autonomy in daily life, unwillingness to be a burden, and relationships. Through the initial assessment, value preferences can be explored and then shared with hospice team members to ensure that services are provided in such a way that their values and preferences are respected. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+in+End-of-Life+%26+Palliative+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Values+Important+to+Terminally+Ill+African+American+Older+Adults+in+Receiving+Hospice+Care&amp;rft.au=Noh%2C+Hyunjin&amp;rft.aulast=Noh&amp;rft.aufirst=Hyunjin&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=338&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+in+End-of-Life+%26+Palliative+Care&amp;rft.issn=15524256&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15524256.2014.975317

Integrating Adolescent Substance Abuse Treatment with HIV Services: Evidence-Based Models and Baseline Descriptions

Author: Murphy, Bridget S; Branson, Christopher E; Francis, Judith; Vaughn, Gretchen Chase; Greene, Alison; Kingwood, Nancy; Adjei, Gifty Ampadu

Publication info: Journal of Evidence-Based Social Work  Vol. 11, Iss. 5,  (January 2014): 445-459.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1680149033?accountid=14667

Abstract: Adolescents with substance use disorders are at high risk for contracting Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)/Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS) and other sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Adolescence is the period of sexual maturation that compounds the issues associated with infection transmission for this risk-taking group. Integrated treatment models for implementing HIV education, counseling, and testing is a promising approach. This study describes four substance abuse treatment programs of varying levels of care that integrated HIV services for adolescents. Additionally, the evidence-based substance abuse treatment and HIV models are discussed and the baseline characteristics presented. The authors provide a discussion and offer recommendations for service implementation and additional research. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Integrating+Adolescent+Substance+Abuse+Treatment+with+HIV+Services%3A+Evidence-Based+Models+and+Baseline+Descriptions&amp;rft.au=Murphy%2C+Bridget+S%3BBranson%2C+Christopher+E%3BFrancis%2C+Judith%3BVaughn%2C+Gretchen+Chase%3BGreene%2C+Alison%3BKingwood%2C+Nancy%3BAdjei%2C+Gifty+Ampadu&amp;rft.aulast=Murphy&amp;rft.aufirst=Bridget&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=445&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15433714.2012.760968

The Girls' Health Screen Pilot Study: A Screening Instrument for Girls in the Juvenile Detention System

Author: Golzari, Mana; Mollen, Cynthia J; Acoca, Leslie

Publication info: Journal of Evidence-Based Social Work  Vol. 11, Iss. 5,  (January 2014): 480-483.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1680149215?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this study was to assess the validity of the Girls' Health Screen as a screening instrument compared to a standard history and physical examination among females entering juvenile detention. Chi-square analyses were performed to evaluate the association between the results of the self-administered screen and the history and physical examination performed by a provider. The screen was administered to 119 females. A number of acute issues were elicited that were also statistically correlated with the history and physical exam making it a valid screen for urgent issues at the time of detention. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Girls%27+Health+Screen+Pilot+Study%3A+A+Screening+Instrument+for+Girls+in+the+Juvenile+Detention+System&amp;rft.au=Golzari%2C+Mana%3BMollen%2C+Cynthia+J%3BAcoca%2C+Leslie&amp;rft.aulast=Golzari&amp;rft.aufirst=Mana&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=480&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15433714.2013.853581

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Girls%27+Health+Screen+Pilot+Study%3A+A+Screening+Instrument+for+Girls+in+the+Juvenile+Detention+System&amp;rft.au=Golzari%2C+Mana%3BMollen%2C+Cynthia+J%3BAcoca%2C+Leslie&amp;rft.aulast=Golzari&amp;rft.aufirst=Mana&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=480&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15433714.2013.853581

____________________________________________________________

Promoting Outcome Achievement in Child Welfare: Predictors of Evidence-Informed Practice

Author: Collins-Camargo, Crystal; Garstka, Teri A

Publication info: Journal of Evidence-Based Social Work  Vol. 11, Iss. 5,  (January 2014): 423-436.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1680149772?accountid=14667

Abstract: The use of data and evidence to inform practice in child welfare is the subject of increased discussion in the literature as well as in agencies striving to achieve child safety, permanency, and well-being. Survey data was collected from workers and supervisors in private agencies providing out-of-home care case management and residential treatment services to children and youth across three states. Hierarchical linear modeling tested the role of goal-oriented teamwork and supervisory practice involving the use of data to assess practice effectiveness in predicting evidence-informed practice. The partially mediated relationship showed that a more goal-oriented approach combined with supervisory practice led to increased use of evidence-informed practice. Implications for promoting evidence-informed practice in child welfare are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Promoting+Outcome+Achievement+in+Child+Welfare%3A+Predictors+of+Evidence-Informed+Practice&amp;rft.au=Collins-Camargo%2C+Crystal%3BGarstka%2C+Teri+A&amp;rft.aulast=Collins-Camargo&amp;rft.aufirst=Crystal&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=423&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15433714.2012.759465

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Promoting+Outcome+Achievement+in+Child+Welfare%3A+Predictors+of+Evidence-Informed+Practice&amp;rft.au=Collins-Camargo%2C+Crystal%3BGarstka%2C+Teri+A&amp;rft.aulast=Collins-Camargo&amp;rft.aufirst=Crystal&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=423&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15433714.2012.759465

Supportive Housing: An Evidence-Based Intervention for Reducing Relapse among Low Income Adults in Addiction Recovery

Author: Collard, Carol S; Lewinson, Terri; Watkins, Karen

Publication info: Journal of Evidence-Based Social Work  Vol. 11, Iss. 5,  (January 2014): 468-479.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1680150075?accountid=14667

Abstract: Within the ranks of the homeless are individuals coping with substance addiction and/or chronic physical or mental disability. Their special needs often pose significant barriers to successfully re-integrate into society. For these individuals, simply securing a roof overhead may not be an adequate solution. Supportive housing combines housing with access to on-site social services to assist persons coping with disabling physical and behavioral health conditions. This study examined whether an association could be found between length of residency in supportive housing and subjective well-being. For the purposes of this study, subjective well-being was measured by length of sobriety, self-efficacy, and employment. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Supportive+Housing%3A+An+Evidence-Based+Intervention+for+Reducing+Relapse+among+Low+Income+Adults+in+Addiction+Recovery&amp;rft.au=Collard%2C+Carol+S%3BLewinson%2C+Terri%3BWatkins%2C+Karen&amp;rft.aulast=Collard&amp;rft.aufirst=Carol&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=468&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15433714.2013.765813

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Supportive+Housing%3A+An+Evidence-Based+Intervention+for+Reducing+Relapse+among+Low+Income+Adults+in+Addiction+Recovery&amp;rft.au=Collard%2C+Carol+S%3BLewinson%2C+Terri%3BWatkins%2C+Karen&amp;rft.aulast=Collard&amp;rft.aufirst=Carol&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=468&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15433714.2013.765813

____________________________________________________________

Reemergence of Policy Practice: A Journey Back to our Roots

Author: Byers, Katharine V11 Indiana University School of Social Work's BSW program on the Bloomington, IN campus

Publication info: Advances in Social Work  Vol. 15, Iss. 1,  (0, 2014): 34-50.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700670547?accountid=14667

Abstract: Many people and events have contributed to a renewed focus on policy practice in social work and social work education, culminating in the inclusion of policy practice as one of the ten core social work competencies in the 2008 Council on Social Work Education EPAS. Robert Schneider, founder of Influencing State Policy, was a key player in elevating policy practice, particularly at the state level, in light of the increasing devolution of social policy decision-making to the states. Other social workers and educators created opportunities for policy scholars and practitioners to collaborate, including Leon Ginsberg and the Policy Conference that he and others initiated. Now a new generation of policy practitioners will continue to educate social workers in policy practice skills in the pursuit of social justice. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Advances+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Reemergence+of+Policy+Practice%3A+A+Journey+Back+to+our+Roots&amp;rft.au=Byers%2C+Katharine+V&amp;rft.aulast=Byers&amp;rft.aufirst=Katharine&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=34&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Advances+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15278565&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Reflections of a Latino in the Social Work Profession

Author: Garcia, Alejandro11 School of Social Work; Aging Studies Institute at Syracuse University in Syracuse, NY

Publication info: Advances in Social Work  Vol. 15, Iss. 1,  (0, 2014): 80-90.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700670550?accountid=14667

Abstract: This is a first-person account of seminal events that have helped shape the rich history and cultural heritage of the social work profession. In examining these events, the author has provided some personal history as a Mexican American growing up in South Texas that provides a historical and value context for his participation in these events. He also discusses his leadership experiences in serving on the national staff of NASW and volunteer leadership experiences in a number of professional organizations during critical times for the profession. Adapted from the source document.

A Shifting Paradigm - Medical to Interactional Model: A Personal History

Author: Shulman, Lawrence11 Professor and Dean Emeritus of the School of Social Work at the University of Buffalo in Buffalo, NY.

Publication info: Advances in Social Work  Vol. 15, Iss. 1,  (0, 2014): 207-229.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700670589?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article chronicles over 50 years of change in the profession with an emphasis on the author's professional experiences and the shift in practice paradigms from the medical model to an interactional model. A number of key phases in this shift are identified and illustrated drawn from the author's work over time. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Advances+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=A+Shifting+Paradigm+-+Medical+to+Interactional+Model%3A+A+Personal+History&amp;rft.au=Shulman%2C+Lawrence&amp;rft.aulast=Shulman&amp;rft.aufirst=Lawrence&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=207&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Advances+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15278565&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

The Professionalization of Baccalaureate-Level Social Work

Author: Sheafor, Bradford W11 Professor Emeritus of Social Work at Colorado State University in Fort Collins, CO

Publication info: Advances in Social Work  Vol. 15, Iss. 1,  (0, 2014): 196-206.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672140?accountid=14667

Abstract: We are occasionally privileged to observe an important event in the history of some aspect of life, but one is rarely an eyewitness to the birth of a profession - or even a specific division of a profession. Nevertheless, along with others, I had the privilege of participating in a series of events over several years that, with hindsight, I realize made me a witness to the birth of baccalaureate social work. This article reflects the perspective of one person engaged in these events and may differ from the observations of other participants. Yet, it represents my best recollection of events that began nearly fifty years ago. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Advances+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Professionalization+of+Baccalaureate-Level+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Sheafor%2C+Bradford+W&amp;rft.aulast=Sheafor&amp;rft.aufirst=Bradford&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=196&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Advances+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15278565&amp;rft_id=info:doi/
