Zine-Making as a Pedagogical Tool for Transformative Learning in Social Work Education

Author: Desyllas, Moshoula Capous1; Sinclair, Allison1 Moshoula Capous Desyllas, California State University Northridge, USA

Publication info: Social Work Education  Vol. 33, Iss. 3,  (April 3, 2014): 296-316.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1531929044?accountid=14667

Abstract: As a collaborative endeavor between teacher and student, we reflect on the process of creating and sharing social justice oriented zines in our classroom. Zines can be used as a pedagogical tool for awareness, education, empowerment and transformation. Created in the form of self-published work of original and/or appropriated texts and images, zines are usually presented in small booklet format in a variety of ways, from computer-printed text to comics to handwritten text. When shared, they represent a subversive form of media to deconstruct stereotypes and hegemonic representations perpetuated by mainstream media. Through our classroom project, we found that zines provided an opportunity for creative expression, connection and collaboration. As an experiential technique, they can serve to raise student self-awareness and allow for a broader understanding of power hierarchies. As a direct action tool they can be useful for promoting active class participation in the movement for social justice. We advocate for integrating arts-based projects in social work education in order to promote more embodied ways of learning and to facilitate personal and societal transformation. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Zine-Making+as+a+Pedagogical+Tool+for+Transformative+Learning+in+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.au=Desyllas%2C+Moshoula+Capous%3BSinclair%2C+Allison&amp;rft.aulast=Desyllas&amp;rft.aufirst=Moshoula&amp;rft.date=2014-04-03&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=296&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=02615479&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02615479.2013.805194

Organisational Factors, Job Satisfaction and Intention to Leave Among Newly Qualified Social Workers in England

Author: Hussein, Shereen1; Moriarty, Jo; Stevens, Martin; Sharpe, Endellion; Manthorpe, Jill1 Shereen Hussein, Jo Moriarty, Martin Stevens & Jill Manthorpe, King's College, London, UK

Publication info: Social Work Education  Vol. 33, Iss. 3,  (April 3, 2014): 381-396.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1531930063?accountid=14667

Abstract: Satisfaction with different organisational elements and aspects of work contributes markedly to overall levels of job satisfaction and intention to leave. For newly qualified social workers (NQSWs), especially immediately after graduation, self-perceived competence and their confidence in their educational preparation are also important. This article reports on a longitudinal study following 280 social work students into social work employment in England using data collected as students and six months after graduation. We focus on their experiences as NQSWs, thus only including those working in social work jobs, reporting the relative importance of their satisfaction with different work elements, such as supervision and job engagement. These are used to construct a model of NQSWs' overall satisfaction and intentions of leaving their social work jobs. The model incorporates NQSWs' perceptions of how well their degree courses prepared them for their current social work jobs in addition to personal, organisational and specific role characteristics. Using statistical techniques of factor analysis and regression modelling we highlight the complexities of how job satisfaction is constructed and we argue that the data reveal the importance of team support and self-efficacy in relation to whether social workers are thinking about leaving their current social work jobs. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Organisational+Factors%2C+Job+Satisfaction+and+Intention+to+Leave+Among+Newly+Qualified+Social+Workers+in+England&amp;rft.au=Hussein%2C+Shereen%3BMoriarty%2C+Jo%3BStevens%2C+Martin%3BSharpe%2C+Endellion%3BManthorpe%2C+Jill&amp;rft.aulast=Hussein&amp;rft.aufirst=Shereen&amp;rft.date=2014-04-03&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=381&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=02615479&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02615479.2013.806467

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Organisational+Factors%2C+Job+Satisfaction+and+Intention+to+Leave+Among+Newly+Qualified+Social+Workers+in+England&amp;rft.au=Hussein%2C+Shereen%3BMoriarty%2C+Jo%3BStevens%2C+Martin%3BSharpe%2C+Endellion%3BManthorpe%2C+Jill&amp;rft.aulast=Hussein&amp;rft.aufirst=Shereen&amp;rft.date=2014-04-03&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=381&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=02615479&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02615479.2013.806467

Faculty Development of a Joint MSW Program Utilizing Tuckman's Model of Stages of Group Development

Author: Seck, Mamadou M1; Helton, Lonnie1 Cleveland State University School of Social Work, Cleveland, Ohio, USA m.seck@csuohio.edu

Publication info: Social Work with Groups  Vol. 37, Iss. 2,  (April 3, 2014): 158-168.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1531930084?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes and analyzes Tuckman's model of the stages of group development, which evolved from a four-phase to a five-phase scheme. The genesis and evolution of the model and its main assumptions and concepts are discussed. The authors present an innovative application of Tuckman's model where faculty members at two different schools of social work employed it as they strived as a group to implement a joint Master of Social Work Program across two different campuses. This application can apply to the tasks of faculty members who frequently implement their internal work or across-systems activities in groups. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Faculty+Development+of+a+Joint+MSW+Program+Utilizing+Tuckman%27s+Model+of+Stages+of+Group+Development&amp;rft.au=Seck%2C+Mamadou+M%3BHelton%2C+Lonnie&amp;rft.aulast=Seck&amp;rft.aufirst=Mamadou&amp;rft.date=2014-04-03&amp;rft.volume=37&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=158&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2013.828908

'Moving In': Difficulties and Support in the Transition to Higher Education for In-service Social Care Students

Author: McSweeney, Fiona11 Department of Social Sciences, Dublin Institute of Technology, Dublin, Ireland

Publication info: Social Work Education  Vol. 33, Iss. 3,  (April 3, 2014): 317-337.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1531930199?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper reports on the difficulties and supports experienced by social care practitioners within the educational institution during their transition to higher education. A life transition such as entering higher education causes stress for individuals and social support is essential in successfully dealing with this stress (Anderson et al., 2012). Fifteen social care practitioners were interviewed twice during and once at the end of their first academic year in college. Findings indicate that participants were reluctant to approach staff for help despite anxiety about classes and assignments. Discussion and debate in class helped learning and contributed to feelings of being valued. 'Moving in' was a slow process with a physical and emotional impact for which they were unprepared. Student peers were a source of emotional and cognitive support but developing relationships took time. By the end of the transition phase participants noted changes and gains in themselves and their work practices. Recommendations are made to aid the transition to higher education for in-service social care practitioners. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=%27Moving+In%27%3A+Difficulties+and+Support+in+the+Transition+to+Higher+Education+for+In-service+Social+Care+Students&amp;rft.au=McSweeney%2C+Fiona&amp;rft.aulast=McSweeney&amp;rft.aufirst=Fiona&amp;rft.date=2014-04-03&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=317&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=02615479&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02615479.2013.770832

Projective Identification and the Fear of Failing: Making Sense of Practice Educators' Experiences of Failing Social Work Students in Practice Learning Settings

Author: Finch, Jo; Schaub, Jason; Dalrymple, Roger

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Practice  Vol. 28, Iss. 2,  (April 3, 2014): 139-154.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1550996592?accountid=14667

Abstract: The study focuses on emotional processes that may arise for practice educators when working with struggling or failing students in practice learning settings. Informed by a thematic review of the literature exploring the phenomenon of 'failing to fail', the study draws on two UK qualitative studies that highlighted the emotional distress experienced by practice educators when working with a marginal or failing student. The study draws key examples from these prior studies and argues that the psychoanalytic concept of projective identification offers a plausible and illuminating account of the states of mind experienced and reported by some practice educators in the 'failing to fail' dilemma. The notion is proffered as a conceptual framework for practice educators to explore and apply to their own practice as a means of making explicit unconscious states of mind, helping to recognise and rationalise these, thus supporting confidence in making appropriate assessment decisions. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Projective+Identification+and+the+Fear+of+Failing%3A+Making+Sense+of+Practice+Educators%27+Experiences+of+Failing+Social+Work+Students+in+Practice+Learning+Settings&amp;rft.au=Finch%2C+Jo%3BSchaub%2C+Jason%3BDalrymple%2C+Roger&amp;rft.aulast=Finch&amp;rft.aufirst=Jo&amp;rft.date=2014-04-03&amp;rft.volume=28&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=139&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650533.2013.854754

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Projective+Identification+and+the+Fear+of+Failing%3A+Making+Sense+of+Practice+Educators%27+Experiences+of+Failing+Social+Work+Students+in+Practice+Learning+Settings&amp;rft.au=Finch%2C+Jo%3BSchaub%2C+Jason%3BDalrymple%2C+Roger&amp;rft.aulast=Finch&amp;rft.aufirst=Jo&amp;rft.date=2014-04-03&amp;rft.volume=28&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=139&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650533.2013.854754

____________________________________________________________

Using Football Metaphor to Engage Men in Therapeutic Support

Author: Spandler, Helen; Roy, Alastair; Mckeown, Mick

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Practice  Vol. 28, Iss. 2,  (April 3, 2014): 229-245.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1550996640?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper is an account of a small scale exploratory study about the use and value of football metaphor as a device for facilitating therapeutic work. It is based on an evaluation which used a range of qualitative and quantitative approaches. In this paper, we selectively draw on the qualitative data to provide examples to inform our discussion. We illustrate various ways in which football metaphor can support therapeutic change: by aiding initial engagement, facilitating mutual support, enabling self-understanding and motivating change. We relate our analysis to the literature about the therapeutic value of metaphor and highlight the salience of using football metaphor in a group-based setting for men who are often seen as 'hard to engage' in therapeutic support. With some caveats, we argue that football metaphor offers a potentially rich and flexible therapeutic resource. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Using+Football+Metaphor+to+Engage+Men+in+Therapeutic+Support&amp;rft.au=Spandler%2C+Helen%3BRoy%2C+Alastair%3BMckeown%2C+Mick&amp;rft.aulast=Spandler&amp;rft.aufirst=Helen&amp;rft.date=2014-04-03&amp;rft.volume=28&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=229&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650533.2013.853286

How a Therapist Responds to Cultural Versus Noncultural Dialogue in Cross-Cultural Clinical Practice

Author: Lee, Eunjung; Horvath, Adam Otto

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Practice  Vol. 28, Iss. 2,  (April 3, 2014): 193-217.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1550997527?accountid=14667

Abstract: A therapist's capacity to respond appropriately to a client is crucial in fostering positive therapeutic relationships and outcomes in general but it is even more important in cross-cultural therapy. Given the clinical significance of the dyad-specific and dynamic nature of the therapist's responsiveness, our study explores one white female therapist's responsiveness with three racial/ethnic minority clients in the beginning phase of therapy sessions. Using the structural analysis of social behavior and conversation analysis, the turn-by-turn intensive analysis of culturally relevant and nonrelevant talk in therapy illustrates how a therapist, who is appropriately and positively responsive to clients in other contexts, becomes disengaged and even negatively oriented during culturally relevant talk. This finding illustrates the challenges involved in maintaining positive engagement and responsiveness in cross-cultural therapeutic communication. Our findings also highlight the usefulness of focusing on moment-to-moment interactions in cross-cultural clinical practice. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=How+a+Therapist+Responds+to+Cultural+Versus+Noncultural+Dialogue+in+Cross-Cultural+Clinical+Practice&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Eunjung%3BHorvath%2C+Adam+Otto&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Eunjung&amp;rft.date=2014-04-03&amp;rft.volume=28&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=193&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650533.2013.821104

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=How+a+Therapist+Responds+to+Cultural+Versus+Noncultural+Dialogue+in+Cross-Cultural+Clinical+Practice&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Eunjung%3BHorvath%2C+Adam+Otto&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Eunjung&amp;rft.date=2014-04-03&amp;rft.volume=28&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=193&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650533.2013.821104

Critical Indigenous Pedagogy of Place: How Centering Hawaiian Epistemology and Values in Practice Affects People on Ecosystemic Levels

Author: Trinidad, Alma M O11 School of Social Work, Portland State University, Portland, Oregon, USA

Publication info: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work  Vol. 23, Iss. 2,  (April 3, 2014): 110-128.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018654?accountid=14667

Abstract: Native Hawaiians face an array of disparities due to structural oppression. Interventions developed by social workers need to be culturally responsive. The process of indigenization is necessary for an intervention to be effective in addressing the needs of a cultural group. This article highlights the growing literature on indigenizing interventions. It examines Critical Indigenous Pedagogy of Place (CIPP) as an approach and method that can facilitate the process of indigenization and the impact it may have on multiple ecosystemic levels. Data are drawn from a case study of a community-based, youth-led farm. A content analysis of the interviews was conducted using critical indigenous qualitative research to build a working conceptual model of CIPP. Findings indicate that CIPP has influence on the individual, family, and community levels as it promotes the use of indigenous epistemology and values. Implications on social work practice and education are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Critical+Indigenous+Pedagogy+of+Place%3A+How+Centering+Hawaiian+Epistemology+and+Values+in+Practice+Affects+People+on+Ecosystemic+Levels&amp;rft.au=Trinidad%2C+Alma+M+O&amp;rft.aulast=Trinidad&amp;rft.aufirst=Alma+M&amp;rft.date=2014-04-03&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=110&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2014.903136

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Critical+Indigenous+Pedagogy+of+Place%3A+How+Centering+Hawaiian+Epistemology+and+Values+in+Practice+Affects+People+on+Ecosystemic+Levels&amp;rft.au=Trinidad%2C+Alma+M+O&amp;rft.aulast=Trinidad&amp;rft.aufirst=Alma+M&amp;rft.date=2014-04-03&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=110&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2014.903136

Promotoras' Efforts to Reduce Alcohol Use among Latino Youths: Engaging Latino Parents in Prevention Efforts

Author: Ayon, Cecilia1; Pena, Veronica; Naddy, Michela Bou Goshn1 School of Social Work, Arizona State University, Phoenix, Arizona, USA

Publication info: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work  Vol. 23, Iss. 2,  (April 3, 2014): 129-147.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660019929?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study presents findings from workshops facilitated by promotoras (indigenous community leaders) in efforts to prevent and reduce alcohol use among Latino youths by engaging Latino parents in prevention efforts. Pre- and posttests consisting of a scale and open-ended questions were completed by workshop participants (i.e., Latino parents, mean age 33.63 with an average of 2 to 3 children). The participants' awareness of the rates, risks, and consequences of alcohol use significantly improved following the intervention (pretest M = 7.99 , SD = 2.12; posttest M = 9.45; SD = 1.67; t(70) = -5.328, p < .001) with a medium effect size (Cohen's d = .77). Four major themes emerged in regards to what parents can do to prevent alcohol use among youths, including open communication, dar el ejemplo (set an example), love, and parental involvement (i.e., support and monitoring). Participants felt the workshops' strengths were the quality of information, the delivery of presentation, and que son madres (that the facilitators are mothers). Few studies document promotoras in substance use prevention efforts with Latinos, who underutilize specialty services. Thus, the promotoras model demonstrates a promising method for reaching this growing population. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Promotoras%27+Efforts+to+Reduce+Alcohol+Use+among+Latino+Youths%3A+Engaging+Latino+Parents+in+Prevention+Efforts&amp;rft.au=Ayon%2C+Cecilia%3BPena%2C+Veronica%3BNaddy%2C+Michela+Bou+Goshn&amp;rft.aulast=Ayon&amp;rft.aufirst=Cecilia&amp;rft.date=2014-04-03&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=129&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2014.903137

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Promotoras%27+Efforts+to+Reduce+Alcohol+Use+among+Latino+Youths%3A+Engaging+Latino+Parents+in+Prevention+Efforts&amp;rft.au=Ayon%2C+Cecilia%3BPena%2C+Veronica%3BNaddy%2C+Michela+Bou+Goshn&amp;rft.aulast=Ayon&amp;rft.aufirst=Cecilia&amp;rft.date=2014-04-03&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=129&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2014.903137

Expression of Ethnic Prejudice in Focus Groups from Agencies Affected by the 9/11 Attacks on the World Trade Center

Author: North, Carol S1; Gordon, Mollie; Kim, You-Seung; Wallace, Nancy E; Smith, Rebecca P; Pfefferbaum, Betty; Hong, Barry A; Ali, Osman; Wang, Chong; Pollio, David E1 The VA North Texas Health Care System, Dallas, Texas, USA

Publication info: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work  Vol. 23, Iss. 2,  (April 3, 2014): 93-109.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660020112?accountid=14667

Abstract: Members of Muslim and Arab-American communities were publicly targeted as suspects and perpetrators of this terrorism. One to two years after the attacks, 145 participants from 6 affected agencies in New York City participated in 22 focus groups to discuss post-disaster psychosocial issues. Ethnic prejudice was reflected in 2% of the comments emerging from these discussions, representing three major subthemes: (1) observations of prejudice toward self or others, (2) personal fear-based or prejudicial attitudes and opinions, and (3) defense of Muslims. The discussion involving prejudice that emerged in these focus groups parallels the upsurge in prejudice reported by other sources after 9/11. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Expression+of+Ethnic+Prejudice+in+Focus+Groups+from+Agencies+Affected+by+the+9%2F11+Attacks+on+the+World+Trade+Center&amp;rft.au=North%2C+Carol+S%3BGordon%2C+Mollie%3BKim%2C+You-Seung%3BWallace%2C+Nancy+E%3BSmith%2C+Rebecca+P%3BPfefferbaum%2C+Betty%3BHong%2C+Barry+A%3BAli%2C+Osman%3BWang%2C+Chong%3BPollio%2C+David+E&amp;rft.aulast=North&amp;rft.aufirst=Carol&amp;rft.date=2014-04-03&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=93&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2014.903134

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Expression+of+Ethnic+Prejudice+in+Focus+Groups+from+Agencies+Affected+by+the+9%2F11+Attacks+on+the+World+Trade+Center&amp;rft.au=North%2C+Carol+S%3BGordon%2C+Mollie%3BKim%2C+You-Seung%3BWallace%2C+Nancy+E%3BSmith%2C+Rebecca+P%3BPfefferbaum%2C+Betty%3BHong%2C+Barry+A%3BAli%2C+Osman%3BWang%2C+Chong%3BPollio%2C+David+E&amp;rft.aulast=North&amp;rft.aufirst=Carol&amp;rft.date=2014-04-03&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=93&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2014.903134

Value Conflicts and Value Priorities: It's Not Just About Religion

Author: Valutis, Stephanie1; Rubin, Deborah; Bell, Melissa1 Department of Sociology, Social Work and Anthropology, Christopher Newport University, Newport News, Virginia

Publication info: Journal of Religion & Spirituality in Social Work  Vol. 33, Iss. 2,  (April 3, 2014): 163-177.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947871?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work ethics and values are the cornerstone of the profession and guide social work practice, education, and policy. Little research has examined the experience of conflict between personal values and professional ethics, or the beliefs of social workers about the prioritization of values within practice. This study explores whether social workers experience conflict between religious values and professional ethics and beliefs about the prioritization of religious values and professional roles. Overall participants reported little experience of value conflict and agreed that professional values supersede religious ones. The interaction of religiosity, political beliefs, primary work function, and sex are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Religion+%26+Spirituality+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Value+Conflicts+and+Value+Priorities%3A+It%27s+Not+Just+About+Religion&amp;rft.au=Valutis%2C+Stephanie%3BRubin%2C+Deborah%3BBell%2C+Melissa&amp;rft.aulast=Valutis&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephanie&amp;rft.date=2014-04-03&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=163&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Religion+%26+Spirituality+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15426432&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15426432.2014.900375

Two-generation preschool programme: immediate and 7-year-old outcomes for low-income children and their parents

Author: Benzies, Karen1; Mychasiuk, Richelle; Kurilova, Jana; Tough, Suzanne; Edwards, Nancy; Donnelly, Carlene1 Faculty of Nursing, University of Calgary

Publication info: Child and Family Social Work  Vol. 19, Iss. 2,  (May 2014): 203-214.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1520315553?accountid=14667

Abstract: Preschool children living in low-income families are at increased risk for poor outcomes; early intervention programmes mitigate these risks. While there is considerable evidence of the effectiveness of centre-based programmes in other jurisdictions, there is limited research about Canadian programmes, specifically programmes that include children and parents. The purpose of this study was to evaluate a single-site, two-generation preschool demonstration programme for low-income families in Canada. A single group, pre-test (programme intake) /post-test (programme exit) design with a 7-year-old follow-up was used. Between intake and exit, significant improvements in receptive language and global development were found among the children, and significant improvements in self-esteem, use of community resources, parenting stress and risk for child maltreatment were found among the parents. These positive improvements were sustained until the children were 7 years old. Public investment in two-generation preschool programmes may mitigate risks for suboptimal child development and improve parental psychosocial outcomes. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Two-generation+preschool+programme%3A+immediate+and+7-year-old+outcomes+for+low-income+children+and+their+parents&amp;rft.au=Benzies%2C+Karen%3BMychasiuk%2C+Richelle%3BKurilova%2C+Jana%3BTough%2C+Suzanne%3BEdwards%2C+Nancy%3BDonnelly%2C+Carlene&amp;rft.aulast=Benzies&amp;rft.aufirst=Karen&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=203&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fj.1365-2206.2012.00894.x

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Two-generation+preschool+programme%3A+immediate+and+7-year-old+outcomes+for+low-income+children+and+their+parents&amp;rft.au=Benzies%2C+Karen%3BMychasiuk%2C+Richelle%3BKurilova%2C+Jana%3BTough%2C+Suzanne%3BEdwards%2C+Nancy%3BDonnelly%2C+Carlene&amp;rft.aulast=Benzies&amp;rft.aufirst=Karen&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=203&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fj.1365-2206.2012.00894.x

____________________________________________________________

Post-secondary transitions of youth emancipated from foster care

Author: Batsche, Catherine1; Hart, Sarah; Ort, Rhonda; Armstrong, Mary; Strozier, Anne; Hummer, Victoria1 Department of Mental Health Law & Policy, University of South Florida.

Publication info: Child and Family Social Work  Vol. 19, Iss. 2,  (May 2014): 174-184.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1520319704?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study investigated the extent to which KnowHow2Go (KH2Go), a national college access campaign developed for first-generation students in the USA, would resonate with youth who had aged out of foster care. Interviews were conducted with 27 youth who were enrolled in a post-secondary programme following emancipation from foster care. We found KH2Go to have a close fit with the experiences of youth who had been in foster care. Four topics emerged as particularly important for youth in our study: money management, work, parenting and transportation. Finally, the study identified attributes these youth demonstrated that contributed to their resilience during the transition process. This study and the data presented pertain to youth living in the south-eastern USA. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Post-secondary+transitions+of+youth+emancipated+from+foster+care&amp;rft.au=Batsche%2C+Catherine%3BHart%2C+Sarah%3BOrt%2C+Rhonda%3BArmstrong%2C+Mary%3BStrozier%2C+Anne%3BHummer%2C+Victoria&amp;rft.aulast=Batsche&amp;rft.aufirst=Catherine&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=174&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fj.1365-2206.2012.00891.x

____________________________________________________________

Competing institutional logics in the development and implementation of integrated treatment for concurrent disorders in Ontario: A case study

Author: Novotna, Gabriela

Publication info: Journal of Social Work  Vol. 14, Iss. 3,  (May 2014): 260-278.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541996056?accountid=14667

Abstract: Summary: Rising health care costs have increased scrutiny on the performance of mental health and substance use services. The specifics of these human service organizations' institutional environments make evaluating their organizational performance a challenging task. This study, based on 27 semi-structured interviews, document analyses and non-participant observation at two treatment programs, explored how two different institutional logics managerial strategies striving for treatment effectiveness and client-centered care guide the implementation of integrated treatment for concurrent disorders in Ontario, Canada. Findings: Treatment services for concurrent disorders have been pressured to adopt more business-like, performance-oriented rationales that are part of corporatist institutional paradigms including, for example, the spread of managerial strategies focused on developing strong performance culture. Such development, however, can conflict with the principles of client-centered, comprehensive care that social workers and other helping professions adhere to. In this regard, the clash of different rationalities brings inconsistencies to the process of developing and implementing integrated treatments for concurrent disorders. Applications: Despite the ideological commitment to comprehensive, individually-tailored and continuous treatment for concurrent disorders, there has been tension between such commitment and the emphasis on abbreviated, manual-based, routinized treatments associated with cost-containment and resource efficiency. This, however, can have serious consequences for treatment planning and treatment delivery, the client-clinician relationship and the displacement of client-centered care by program-centered approaches. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Competing+institutional+logics+in+the+development+and+implementation+of+integrated+treatment+for+concurrent+disorders+in+Ontario%3A+A+case+study&amp;rft.au=Novotna%2C+Gabriela&amp;rft.aulast=Novotna&amp;rft.aufirst=Gabriela&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=260&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313476613

____________________________________________________________

Economic Necessity or Noble Cause? A Qualitative Study Exploring Motivations for Gestational Surrogacy in Gujarat, India

Author: Karandikar, Sharvari1; Gezinski, Lindsay B; Carter, James R; Kaloga, Marissa1 The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, USA karandikar-chheda.1@osu.edu

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 2,  (May 2014): 224-236.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541996088?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this qualitative study, in-depth interviews were conducted with 15 surrogates from India. Two themes are discussed: (1) motivations for becoming surrogates and (2) role of family and community in surrogacy. The respondents were illiterate women aged 21-30 years and had been surrogate mothers an average of 2 times. Motivations for surrogacy were financial in nature. Surrogates reported stigma from extended family and community forcing them to leave their homes and relocate after surrogacy. This study recommends counseling and psychosocial support services to women and change in policy to execute a stringent law to protect the rights of surrogates. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Economic+Necessity+or+Noble+Cause%3F+A+Qualitative+Study+Exploring+Motivations+for+Gestational+Surrogacy+in+Gujarat%2C+India&amp;rft.au=Karandikar%2C+Sharvari%3BGezinski%2C+Lindsay+B%3BCarter%2C+James+R%3BKaloga%2C+Marissa&amp;rft.aulast=Karandikar&amp;rft.aufirst=Sharvari&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=224&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913516455

____________________________________________________________

Religious and non-religious components in substance abuse treatment: A comparative analysis of faith-based and secular interventions

Author: Davis, Margot Trotter11 Brandeis University, Massachusetts, USA margotd@brandeis.edu

Publication info: Journal of Social Work  Vol. 14, Iss. 3,  (May 2014): 243-259.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541996091?accountid=14667

Abstract: Summary: Recently, faith-based organizations have become increasingly welcomed as government partners in providing services for chronic social problems. In many countries including the United States policies permit social service and healthcare providers that utilize religious practices to be eligible for public funding. The government's support of faith-based programs has provided increased capacity and gives clients more choice in providers. However, providers and policy makers have limited knowledge about the nature and treatment regimen of faith-based interventions. This qualitative study examined 28 faith-based and 27 secular substance abuse treatment programs in the United States using grounded theory methods to develop models of religious influences. Findings: The comparison yielded major differences. Secular programs allow religious practices but consider them voluntary components. Faith-based programs adopt one of the two strategies. Some selectively introduce religious practices but separate them from other treatment activities. Others regard religious practices as essential to recovery and require participation in religious observance. Application: This article describes the conceptual dimensions of religious practices in substance abuse treatment programs and will inform policy makers and practitioners about the role of religion in faith-based and secular programs. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Religious+and+non-religious+components+in+substance+abuse+treatment%3A+A+comparative+analysis+of+faith-based+and+secular+interventions&amp;rft.au=Davis%2C+Margot+Trotter&amp;rft.aulast=Davis&amp;rft.aufirst=Margot&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=243&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313476589

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Religious+and+non-religious+components+in+substance+abuse+treatment%3A+A+comparative+analysis+of+faith-based+and+secular+interventions&amp;rft.au=Davis%2C+Margot+Trotter&amp;rft.aulast=Davis&amp;rft.aufirst=Margot&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=243&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313476589

____________________________________________________________

'Flying' Female Sex Workers Perceptions of HIV Risk and NGOs Sexual Health Outreach Projects: A Case Study of HIV Prevention in Kolkata, India

Author: Sinha, Sunny11 School of Social Work & Administrative Studies, Marywood University, Scranton, PA, USA sinha.sunny@marywood.edu

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 2,  (May 2014): 206-223.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541996096?accountid=14667

Abstract: Based on my 7 months of ethnographic research with 'flying' or mobile female sex workers (FSWs) in the eastern metropolitan city of Kolkata, India, I argue that the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) prevention programs have a limited outreach and impact within the community because of the fundamental differences in how the nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) staff and flying FSWs perceive the risk of HIV. This article examines flying FSWs perceptions of HIV risk and the NGOs sexual health outreach services. Further, the implications for HIV prevention programs and social work practice are discussed. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=%27Flying%27+Female+Sex+Workers+Perceptions+of+HIV+Risk+and+NGOs+Sexual+Health+Outreach+Projects%3A+A+Case+Study+of+HIV+Prevention+in+Kolkata%2C+India&amp;rft.au=Sinha%2C+Sunny&amp;rft.aulast=Sinha&amp;rft.aufirst=Sunny&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=206&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913516450

____________________________________________________________

Exploring Epistemic Injustice Through Feminist Social Work Research

Author: Bell, Karen11 Social Work, School of Humanities and Social Sciences, Charles Sturt University, Wagga Wagga, Australia kbell@csu.edu.au

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 2,  (May 2014): 165-177.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541996129?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores women's experiences of assisted reproduction (AR) and epistemic injustice. Using feminist theory and qualitative data from a social work research project, I argue that the dominant discourse in AR is partial and inadequate and that these epistemological oversights are not accidental; the oversights are actively maintained to preserve power relationships and this constitutes epistemic injustice. Yet women are not completely silenced; elements of resistance and attempts to restore epistemic agency are also presented. The need for an epistemologically inclusive approach to AR and epistemic justice through social work research is reinforced. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+Epistemic+Injustice+Through+Feminist+Social+Work+Research&amp;rft.au=Bell%2C+Karen&amp;rft.aulast=Bell&amp;rft.aufirst=Karen&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=165&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913516457

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+Epistemic+Injustice+Through+Feminist+Social+Work+Research&amp;rft.au=Bell%2C+Karen&amp;rft.aulast=Bell&amp;rft.aufirst=Karen&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=165&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913516457

Traumatic Transitions: Homeless Women's Narratives of Abuse, Loss, and Fear

Author: Lewinson, Terri1; Thomas, M Lori; White, Shaneureka1 School of Social Work, Georgia State University, Atlanta, GA, USA tlewinson@gsu.edu

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 2,  (May 2014): 192-205.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541996154?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents traumatic experiences among 21 women residing in budget hotels after housing displacement. Framed in feminist and cumulative trauma theories, the purpose of this study was to explore types of trauma and adversity prior to and during housing at budget hotels. In this qualitative study, narrative and categorical content-analysis approaches were conducted to identify common themes across women's narratives. Findings revealed trauma narratives of physical and emotional abuse, childhood maltreatment, loss, financial exploitation, sexual intimidation, eviction anxiety, environmental stress, crime exposure, and systematic subjugation. Trauma-informed intervention approaches for social work practice are outlined to promote women's empowerment. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Traumatic+Transitions%3A+Homeless+Women%27s+Narratives+of+Abuse%2C+Loss%2C+and+Fear&amp;rft.au=Lewinson%2C+Terri%3BThomas%2C+M+Lori%3BWhite%2C+Shaneureka&amp;rft.aulast=Lewinson&amp;rft.aufirst=Terri&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=192&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913516449

A Look Back at the Defense of Marriage Act: Why Same-Sex Marriage Is Still Relevant for Social Work

Author: Pelts, Michael D11 University of Missouri, Columbia, MO, USA mdpp74@mail.missouri.edu

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 2,  (May 2014): 237-247.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541996163?accountid=14667

Abstract: The social work profession has made a commitment to serve people who are marginalized and address issues at the direct practice level and the policy level. Beyond the Defense of Marriage Act, marriage inequality in the United States negatively impacts millions of individuals and families. A review of the history of same-sex marriage (SSM) and the current state of SSM suggests that actions at the state level continue to have far-reaching negative impacts. Issues of marriage equality and families headed by same-sex couples will require the advocacy and support of social work for decades to come. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=A+Look+Back+at+the+Defense+of+Marriage+Act%3A+Why+Same-Sex+Marriage+Is+Still+Relevant+for+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Pelts%2C+Michael+D&amp;rft.aulast=Pelts&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=237&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913519793

Personalisation, family relationships and autism: Conceptualising the role of adult siblings

Author: Atkin, Karl1; Tozer, Rosemary1 University of York, England, UK karl.atkin@york.ac.uk

Publication info: Journal of Social Work  Vol. 14, Iss. 3,  (May 2014): 225-242.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541996340?accountid=14667

Abstract: Summary: Current policy discourses demonstrate a weak connection to broader theoretical debates about family obligation and in particular how family responsibilities become negotiated over time and across the life course. How policy imagines family care can, therefore, be different to the actual experiences of families. This qualitative paper, using semi-structured interviews, explores the experience of a particularly neglected group, adult siblings, who have a brother or sister with autism (plus learning disability). We spoke to 21 adult siblings, met with 12 of their siblings with autism and talked to 12 health and social care professionals. Findings: Our analysis suggests that connectedness and commitment, which remained subject to continuous redefinition by all family members, informed sibling relationships Practitioners, however, struggle to engage with this complexity, thereby undermining the extent siblings' relationships can be realised. Application: The paper concludes that policy initiatives are at risk of becoming an uneasy compromise, in which the need to offer choice occurs alongside the 'problem' of managing family care. Sibling relationships are more than simply 'being of' or 'belonging to' a family. They are dynamic, subject to contingency and negotiation. Interventions should be formulated to work with these assumptions, without presupposing a definite experience fixed in time and space. This would not only maximise the disabled siblings' quality of life, but also ensure a more productive and fulfilling context for family relationships. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Personalisation%2C+family+relationships+and+autism%3A+Conceptualising+the+role+of+adult+siblings&amp;rft.au=Atkin%2C+Karl%3BTozer%2C+Rosemary&amp;rft.aulast=Atkin&amp;rft.aufirst=Karl&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=225&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313476453

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Personalisation%2C+family+relationships+and+autism%3A+Conceptualising+the+role+of+adult+siblings&amp;rft.au=Atkin%2C+Karl%3BTozer%2C+Rosemary&amp;rft.aulast=Atkin&amp;rft.aufirst=Karl&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=225&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313476453

Educating for International Social Work: Human rights leadership

Author: Hawkins, Catherine Allensworth; Knox, Karen

Publication info: International Social Work  Vol. 57, Iss. 3,  (May 2014): 248-257.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541996998?accountid=14667

Abstract: As social work increasingly develops an international perspective, there is a need for educational approaches that more fully integrate this content into the curriculum. This article presents an instructional framework focused on developing global leadership using the theme of universal human rights. It encourages students to analyze oppressive practices of power and to pursue equality for all people through acquiring human rights literacy (knowledge), empathy (values), responsibility (action), and transforming this into global leadership (change). It provides examples of teaching strategies that assist students in developing an international perspective to guide social work practice in the global 21st century. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Educating+for+International+Social+Work%3A+Human+rights+leadership&amp;rft.au=Hawkins%2C+Catherine+Allensworth%3BKnox%2C+Karen&amp;rft.aulast=Hawkins&amp;rft.aufirst=Catherine&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=57&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=248&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0020872813519462

Cultural Factors in the Treatment of Battered Women With Privilege: Domestic Violence in the Lives of White European-American, Middle-Class, Heterosexual Women

Author: Berg, Kathryn K11 Loyola University Chicago, Chicago, IL, USA berg.kathrynk@gmail.com

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 2,  (May 2014): 142-152.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541997614?accountid=14667

Abstract: The field of social work pathologizes marginalized cultures by neglecting to explicitly identify cultural factors in the lives of women with systemic privilege due to race, class, and sexual orientation. This article discusses the importance of examining privilege as a strategy for advancing cultural competency in the treatment of battered women. Cultural factors in the lives of White European-American, middle-class, heterosexual women in intimate partnerships with men who share their privileges, referred to as 'dominant culture women,' are explored. Additional scholarship which identifies cultural factors placing this population at risk is needed to advance cultural competency in domestic violence interventions. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Cultural+Factors+in+the+Treatment+of+Battered+Women+With+Privilege%3A+Domestic+Violence+in+the+Lives+of+White+European-American%2C+Middle-Class%2C+Heterosexual+Women&amp;rft.au=Berg%2C+Kathryn+K&amp;rft.aulast=Berg&amp;rft.aufirst=Kathryn&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=142&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913516448

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Cultural+Factors+in+the+Treatment+of+Battered+Women+With+Privilege%3A+Domestic+Violence+in+the+Lives+of+White+European-American%2C+Middle-Class%2C+Heterosexual+Women&amp;rft.au=Berg%2C+Kathryn+K&amp;rft.aulast=Berg&amp;rft.aufirst=Kathryn&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=142&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913516448

____________________________________________________________

Educating for the Global Agenda: Internationally relevant conceptual frameworks and knowledge for social work education

Author: Healy, Lynne M; Wairire, Gidraph G

Publication info: International Social Work  Vol. 57, Iss. 3,  (May 2014): 235-247.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541999663?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this article, we discuss the capacity of social work educational programs to prepare graduates to contribute to the human, social and environmental challenges outlined in the Global Agenda for Social Work and Social Development. The educational sector must play a lead role through training and research. Using examples from Kenya and the United States, we argue more curriculum emphasis on such areas as social and economic development, human rights, and social integration is required. The article concludes with recommendations for strengthening curriculum and dialogue on the globally relevant concepts identified in the Global Agenda. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Educating+for+the+Global+Agenda%3A+Internationally+relevant+conceptual+frameworks+and+knowledge+for+social+work+education&amp;rft.au=Healy%2C+Lynne+M%3BWairire%2C+Gidraph+G&amp;rft.aulast=Healy&amp;rft.aufirst=Lynne&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=57&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=235&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0020872813519463

A Review of the Provision of Intervention Programs for Female Victims and Survivors of Domestic Abuse in the United Kingdom

Author: Williamson, Emma1; Abrahams, Hilary1 Centre for Gender and Violence Research, School for Policy Studies, University of Bristol, Bristol, UK e.williamson@bristol.ac.uk

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 2,  (May 2014): 178-191.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541999879?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article is concerned with the provision of intervention programs aimed at female victims/survivors of domestic abuse in the United Kingdom. Social workers, and other statutory professionals, are increasingly referring clients who have experienced abuse to these interventions, but there has been little debate about the aims and objectives of them or consideration of their effectiveness. This article includes a discussion of the key elements of the programs and criticisms of these types of interventions. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=A+Review+of+the+Provision+of+Intervention+Programs+for+Female+Victims+and+Survivors+of+Domestic+Abuse+in+the+United+Kingdom&amp;rft.au=Williamson%2C+Emma%3BAbrahams%2C+Hilary&amp;rft.aulast=Williamson&amp;rft.aufirst=Emma&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=178&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913516452

Conceptualizing Social Determinants of Maternal and Infant Health Disparities

Author: Klawetter, Susanne11 University of Denver, Denver, CO, USA susanne.klawetter@du.edu

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 2,  (May 2014): 131-141.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541999948?accountid=14667

Abstract: Research demonstrates that women and children within marginalized ethnic and racial groups and those living in poverty experience disparate health outcomes. These disparities have immediate and long-term consequences. Exploring two theories used to examine social determinants of health-life course perspective and historical trauma response, this article will explain the major premises of each, provide application examples, compare and examine utility for practice, and highlight areas for future research. A theoretical critique will be included, as well as insight into how these theories together might address gaps as an approach to maternal and infant health research and practice. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Conceptualizing+Social+Determinants+of+Maternal+and+Infant+Health+Disparities&amp;rft.au=Klawetter%2C+Susanne&amp;rft.aulast=Klawetter&amp;rft.aufirst=Susanne&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=131&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913516451

A Postcolonial Feminist Social Work Perspective on Global Food Insecurity

Author: Deepak, Anne C11 Texas State University San Marcos, San Marcos, TX, USA ad21@txstate.edu

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 2,  (May 2014): 153-164.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1542000066?accountid=14667

Abstract: A postcolonial feminist social work (PCFSW) perspective is an essential theoretical framework with which to analyze global food insecurity and proposed solutions to this urgent social problem. In this article, the PCFSW perspective is elaborated, and the arguments of two groups of global stakeholders that identify women's empowerment and gender equity as crucial to the solution are presented and analyzed. The analysis concludes that food sovereignty aided by agroecology is most suited to social work as it is grounded in the concerns of peasant women, the group most affected by food insecurity and the proposed policies to combat this problem. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=A+Postcolonial+Feminist+Social+Work+Perspective+on+Global+Food+Insecurity&amp;rft.au=Deepak%2C+Anne+C&amp;rft.aulast=Deepak&amp;rft.aufirst=Anne&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=153&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913516456

Treatment Effects of a Relationship-Strengthening Intervention for Economically Disadvantaged New Parents

Author: Charles, Pajarita1; Jones, Anne; Guo, Shenyang1 School of Social Service Administration, University of Chicago, Chicago, IL, USA pcharles@uchicago.edu

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (May 2014): 321-338.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1542000518?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objective: The purpose of the present study was to evaluate the treatment effects of a relationship skills and family strengthening intervention for n = 726 high-risk, disadvantaged new parents. Method: Hierarchical linear modeling and regression models were used to assess intervention treatment effects. These findings were subsequently verified through two sensitivity analyses using propensity score analysis and growth curve modeling. Results: Analyses indicated 6 of 10 beneficial treatment effects were statistically significant, including relationship satisfaction, relationship quality, communication, conflict resolution, arguing, and emotional abuse. Most of these effects were verified in the more rigorous sensitivity analyses. Conclusion: Study findings suggest that this intervention is effective in helping disadvantaged couples improve relationship skills and strengthen family bonds. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Treatment+Effects+of+a+Relationship-Strengthening+Intervention+for+Economically+Disadvantaged+New+Parents&amp;rft.au=Charles%2C+Pajarita%3BJones%2C+Anne%3BGuo%2C+Shenyang&amp;rft.aulast=Charles&amp;rft.aufirst=Pajarita&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=321&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731513497803

____________________________________________________________

Training Social Work Graduate Students in the Evidence-Based Practice Process

Author: Bender, Kimberly1; Altschul, Inna; Yoder, Jamie; Parrish, Danielle; Nickels, Sarah J1 Graduate School of Social Work, University of Denver, Denver, CO, USA kimberly.bender@du.edu

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (May 2014): 339-348.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1542001026?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objective: This study tested the effects of integrating evidence-based practice (EBP) process material into a research curriculum for master of social work (MSW) students. Methods: A quasi-experimental design (N = 152) was used across 12 sections of a required program evaluation course, with half integrating EBP process material and half using the traditional curriculum. A version of the Evidence-based Practice Process Assessment scale (EBPPAS) was administered at the beginning and end of the course. Analyses examined changes from pre- to posttest on EBPPAS subscales and assessed group differences. Results: At posttest, the EBP group had significantly higher ratings than the comparison group on the familiarity subscale. Both groups' scores significantly increased at posttest on the familiarity with and engagement in the EBP process subscales. Conclusions: MSW students' participation in a traditional program evaluation course is associated with increased EBP self-efficacy, and intentional introduction of EBP process material may further these outcomes. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Training+Social+Work+Graduate+Students+in+the+Evidence-Based+Practice+Process&amp;rft.au=Bender%2C+Kimberly%3BAltschul%2C+Inna%3BYoder%2C+Jamie%3BParrish%2C+Danielle%3BNickels%2C+Sarah+J&amp;rft.aulast=Bender&amp;rft.aufirst=Kimberly&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=339&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731513506614

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Training+Social+Work+Graduate+Students+in+the+Evidence-Based+Practice+Process&amp;rft.au=Bender%2C+Kimberly%3BAltschul%2C+Inna%3BYoder%2C+Jamie%3BParrish%2C+Danielle%3BNickels%2C+Sarah+J&amp;rft.aulast=Bender&amp;rft.aufirst=Kimberly&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=339&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731513506614

____________________________________________________________

Validation of the Revised BSI-18 With Latino Migrant Day Laborers

Author: Negi, Nalini Junko1; Iwamoto, Derek Kenji1 School of Social Work, University of Maryland, Baltimore, MD, USA nnegi@ssw.umaryland.edu

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (May 2014): 364-371.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1542001032?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objective: This study examines the factor structure of the Brief Symptom Inventory-18 (BSI-18; Derogatis, 2001) in a hard-to-reach population of mainly undocumented migrant Latino day laborers. While, the BSI-18 has been found to be a valid and reliable measure of psychological distress, cross-cultural assessments in sub-groups of Latinos are scarce with this being the first study to examine the factor structure of the Spanish version of the BSI-18 with this population. Methods: A series of principal axis exploratory factor analytic procedures examining one to three-factor models were performed with a street recruited sample of 150 Latino migrant day laborers. Results: A one-factor model emerged and four items were dropped due to low factor loadings. The internal consistency coefficients for the 14-item BSI was alpha = .87. Conclusions: Findings suggest that the revised BSI-18 appears to measure a single dimension of general somatic-psychological distress in this sample of Latinos. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Validation+of+the+Revised+BSI-18+With+Latino+Migrant+Day+Laborers&amp;rft.au=Negi%2C+Nalini+Junko%3BIwamoto%2C+Derek+Kenji&amp;rft.aulast=Negi&amp;rft.aufirst=Nalini&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=364&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731513507980

Exploring the Formal Supports Used by People Bereaved Through Suicide: A Qualitative Study

Author: McKinnon, Janette M1; Chonody, Jill1 School of Psychology, Social Work, and Social Policy, University of South Australia, Clarence Park, South Australia, Australia

Publication info: Social Work in Mental Health  Vol. 12, Iss. 3,  (May 2014): 231-248.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1550996845?accountid=14667

Abstract: Approximately seven Australians take their own lives every day (Mendoza & Rosenberg, 2010), which means that thousands of survivors will require support for their unique grief each year. This study seeks to better understand the personal lived experiences of people bereaved by suicide by exploring their use of formal supports and identifying any unmet needs. In this phenomenological study, 14 individuals bereaved by suicide were interviewed. Thematic analysis of the data identified two major themes supports in the immediate aftermath and ongoing supports. Survivors were inconsistently connected with service providers or provided with information regarding available services. The response of first responders and other professionals influenced the bereavement journey for suicide survivors, and the participants' lived experience ranged from compassionate to cold. Continuing study into postvention is critical to ensure that available supports can meet the needs of those grieving after a suicide. Such efforts may help avert complications associated with the suicide of a loved one. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Mental+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+the+Formal+Supports+Used+by+People+Bereaved+Through+Suicide%3A+A+Qualitative+Study&amp;rft.au=McKinnon%2C+Janette+M%3BChonody%2C+Jill&amp;rft.aulast=McKinnon&amp;rft.aufirst=Janette&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=12&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=231&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Mental+Health&amp;rft.issn=15332985&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15332985.2014.889637

Disparities in Insurance Coverage among Children with Special Health Care Needs: How Social Workers Can Promote Social and Economic Justice

Author: Wilson, Kasey1; Hirschi, Melissa; Comeau, Margaret; Bronheim, Suzanne; Bachman, Sara S1 Research Assistant, School of Social Work, Boston University wilsonka@bu.edu

Publication info: Health & Social Work  Vol. 39, Iss. 2,  (May 2014): 121-127.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1567042018?accountid=14667

Abstract: The federal Maternal and Child Health Bureau (MCHB) defines children with special health care needs (CSHCN) as "those who have or are at increased risk for a chronic physical, developmental, behavioral, or emotional condition and who also require health and related services of a type or amount beyond that required by children generally" (U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, 2013). About 15 percent of U.S. children have special health care needs, and 23 percent of families have at least one child with a special health care need (U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, 2013). Because almost half of all social workers are child, family, and school social workers (National Association of Social Workers, 2011), children whose physical, medical, behavioral, emotional, and mental health needs may classify them as having a special health care need are a population of particular interest to the social work community. Although it is important for all children to have insurance coverage (because having a way to pay for care enables access to care), this is particularly important for CSHCN because they require more health services than their peers and are more vulnerable to adverse outcomes when they experience access to care barriers. The MCHB outlines six core outcomes to improve the system of care for CSHCN; the health insurance core outcome requires that "families of CSHCN have adequate private and/or public insurance to pay for the services they need" (U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, 2013). Progress in achieving this goal is evidenced by the fact that the likelihood of meeting the core outcome for all CSHCN has increased over the past decade (Honberg, Kogan, Allen, Strickland, & Newacheck, 2009; Honberg, McPherson, Strickland, Gage, & Newacheck, 2005). However, insurance coverage among CSHCN is not equitably distributed; there are significant disparities based on race, ethnicity, language, socioeconomic status, and functional limitation (Honberg et al., 2005, 2009; Javier, Huffman, Mendoza, & Wise, 2009; Liu et al., 2005; Newacheck, Hung, & Wright, 2002; Skinner, Slifkin, & Mayer, 2006; Yu, Nyman, Kogan, Huang, & Schwalberg, 2004). Because commitment to social and economic justice is a key value of the social work profession, there is an important role for social workers to play in reducing disparities in insurance coverage for CSHCN, particularly those who may be underserved by the current health care system. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Disparities+in+Insurance+Coverage+among+Children+with+Special+Health+Care+Needs%3A+How+Social+Workers+Can+Promote+Social+and+Economic+Justice&amp;rft.au=Wilson%2C+Kasey%3BHirschi%2C+Melissa%3BComeau%2C+Margaret%3BBronheim%2C+Suzanne%3BBachman%2C+Sara+S&amp;rft.aulast=Wilson&amp;rft.aufirst=Kasey&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=121&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Disparities+in+Insurance+Coverage+among+Children+with+Special+Health+Care+Needs%3A+How+Social+Workers+Can+Promote+Social+and+Economic+Justice&amp;rft.au=Wilson%2C+Kasey%3BHirschi%2C+Melissa%3BComeau%2C+Margaret%3BBronheim%2C+Suzanne%3BBachman%2C+Sara+S&amp;rft.aulast=Wilson&amp;rft.aufirst=Kasey&amp;rft.date=2014-05-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=121&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/
