Implementing Rigorous Survey Methodology within Contexts of Social Work Education, Training and Practice: A Case Study in Substance Use

Author: Hutchinson, Aisha1; Allnock, Debra1 University of Bedfordshire, UK

Publication info: Social Work Education  Vol. 33, Iss. 5,  (July 4, 2014): 605-618.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018937?accountid=14667

Abstract: With the integration of evidence-based practice central to all areas of social work education and training across the globe, it is crucial that we continue to engage with the methodological challenges inherent in gathering this evidence, particularly when it is related to the nature of social work education itself. As a result, this paper addresses some of the methodological challenges involved in examining the education available to social workers on engaging with substance use, both within the social work academy and local authorities in England. Drawing on experiences of implementing large scale online surveys from three substantial research projects completed by the authors, this paper highlights four methodological themes: (1) Constructing a representative sampling frame; (2) Identifying participants within organisations with many departments; (3) Response rates; and (4) Questionnaire design. While these are familiar methodological considerations, this article draws attention to the specific complexities of gathering 'representative' knowledge to inform educational strategies on substance use within social work education and employment contexts. Finally this paper offers lessons learned and guidance for social work academics, students and practitioners who are minded to build, or draw from, an evidence-base using representative samples from and within these environments. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Implementing+Rigorous+Survey+Methodology+within+Contexts+of+Social+Work+Education%2C+Training+and+Practice%3A+A+Case+Study+in+Substance+Use&amp;rft.au=Hutchinson%2C+Aisha%3BAllnock%2C+Debra&amp;rft.aulast=Hutchinson&amp;rft.aufirst=Aisha&amp;rft.date=2014-07-04&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=605&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=02615479&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02615479.2014.919071

The Extent and Nature of Practitioners, Encounters with Alcohol and Other Drug Use in Social Work and Social Care Practice

Author: Dance, Cherilyn1; Galvani, Sarah; Hutchinson, Aisha1 University of Bedfordshire, UK

Publication info: Social Work Education  Vol. 33, Iss. 5,  (July 4, 2014): 557-572.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018947?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article considers the extent and nature of social work and social care practitioners' experience of working with service users whose lives are affected by the problematic use of alcohol or other drugs (AOD). It draws on the findings of a national study of 'working with alcohol and drug use' which was conducted in England in 2010-2011. The study reported here comprised an online survey of front-line practitioners (n = 597), complemented by 12 practitioner focus groups and interviews with 21 key informants from participating local authorities and substance use treatment services. This paper focuses primarily on data from one element of the survey. Findings indicate that the great majority of staff encountered service users who are affected by AOD problems at some level, although there were differences between groups of practitioners in the extent and nature of AOD problems for different groups of service users. The differential experiences of staff according to their client groups underlines the need for education and professional development not only to provide training on working with AOD but to ensure that training is contextualised and relevant to practitioners across the range of social work and social care services. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=The+Extent+and+Nature+of+Practitioners%2C+Encounters+with+Alcohol+and+Other+Drug+Use+in+Social+Work+and+Social+Care+Practice&amp;rft.au=Dance%2C+Cherilyn%3BGalvani%2C+Sarah%3BHutchinson%2C+Aisha&amp;rft.aulast=Dance&amp;rft.aufirst=Cherilyn&amp;rft.date=2014-07-04&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=557&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=02615479&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02615479.2014.919066

Young Adult Cancer Survivors and the Challenges of Intimacy

Author: Robinson, Lynne1; Miedema, Baukje; Easley, Julie1 School of Health and Human Performance, Dalhousie University, Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada

Publication info: Journal of Psychosocial Oncology  Vol. 32, Iss. 4,  (July 4, 2014): 447-462.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947252?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this study was to explore intimate relationships after a cancer diagnosis, applying constructivist grounded theory to interviews with 55 Canadian young adult cancer survivors. The core category found was the dynamic interplay between participants' experiences of cancer and their intimate relationships. The authors found four themes within this core category: the mental experience of cancer, challenged sexual intimacy, the relationship response to strain (supportive or nonsupportive), and adapted intimacy. This research demonstrates the importance of intimate relationships for young adults along their cancer trajectory, revealing that those relationships are severely strained by a cancer diagnosis and treatment yet help to limit negative consequences. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Young+Adult+Cancer+Survivors+and+the+Challenges+of+Intimacy&amp;rft.au=Robinson%2C+Lynne%3BMiedema%2C+Baukje%3BEasley%2C+Julie&amp;rft.aulast=Robinson&amp;rft.aufirst=Lynne&amp;rft.date=2014-07-04&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=447&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F07347332.2014.917138

Dusted Community: Piloting a Virtual Peer-to-Peer Support Community for People with an Asbestos-Related Diagnosis and Their Families

Author: Kozlowski, Desiree1; Provost, Stephen Campbell; Tucker, Julie; van der Zwan, Rick1 Discipline of Psychology, Southern Cross University, Coffs Harbour, NSW, Australia

Publication info: Journal of Psychosocial Oncology  Vol. 32, Iss. 4,  (July 4, 2014): 463-475.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947334?accountid=14667

Abstract: Individuals with an asbestos-related diagnosis and their carers face burdens including debilitating and life-limiting physical symptoms and medico-legal stressors. Feelings of social isolation are common. Increasing social connectedness can lead to increased feelings of personal empowerment and may inhibit chronic stress responses. The authors report on the development, via a process of participatory action research, of an online peer-to-peer support group, and the first 30-day test phase of this virtual community. Initial indications are that individuals with an asbestos-related diagnosis and their carers can benefit, in psychosocial terms, from membership of an on-line support group comprised of experientially similar others. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Dusted+Community%3A+Piloting+a+Virtual+Peer-to-Peer+Support+Community+for+People+with+an+Asbestos-Related+Diagnosis+and+Their+Families&amp;rft.au=Kozlowski%2C+Desiree%3BProvost%2C+Stephen+Campbell%3BTucker%2C+Julie%3Bvan+der+Zwan%2C+Rick&amp;rft.aulast=Kozlowski&amp;rft.aufirst=Desiree&amp;rft.date=2014-07-04&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=463&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F07347332.2014.917142

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Dusted+Community%3A+Piloting+a+Virtual+Peer-to-Peer+Support+Community+for+People+with+an+Asbestos-Related+Diagnosis+and+Their+Families&amp;rft.au=Kozlowski%2C+Desiree%3BProvost%2C+Stephen+Campbell%3BTucker%2C+Julie%3Bvan+der+Zwan%2C+Rick&amp;rft.aulast=Kozlowski&amp;rft.aufirst=Desiree&amp;rft.date=2014-07-04&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=463&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F07347332.2014.917142

Social Work and the DSM: A Qualitative Examination of Opinions

Author: Hitchens, Kristine1; Becker, Dana1 Family Services, Father Martin's Ashley, Havre de Grace, Maryland, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Mental Health  Vol. 12, Iss. 4,  (July 4, 2014): 303-329.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947550?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work has had an irresolute association with the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM), and it has been suggested that social workers have been a relatively silent majority when it comes to critiques of the DSM. This study examined social workers' attitudes towards the DSM via semi-structured interviews completed with twenty experienced social workers. Data revealed both ambivalence and unease in relation to what the DSM represents sufficient to suggest that social workers might be encouraged collectively to champion a new method of assessment that is more congruent with the mission of social work. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Mental+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+and+the+DSM%3A+A+Qualitative+Examination+of+Opinions&amp;rft.au=Hitchens%2C+Kristine%3BBecker%2C+Dana&amp;rft.aulast=Hitchens&amp;rft.aufirst=Kristine&amp;rft.date=2014-07-04&amp;rft.volume=12&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=303&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Mental+Health&amp;rft.issn=15332985&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15332985.2013.812540

____________________________________________________________

Will the Treatment Protocols for Schizophrenia be Changing Soon?

Author: Littrell, Jill Leslie11 Social Work, Georgia State University, Tucker, Georgia, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Mental Health  Vol. 12, Iss. 4,  (July 4, 2014): 365-385.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947804?accountid=14667

Abstract: In recent decades the understanding of the core physiology giving rise to schizophrenia has advanced markedly. Current pharmacological interventions fail to target the core problems in schizophrenia. Several important outcome studies call into question whether current medications actually make long-term outcomes worse. These new studies follow the recognized negative side effect of anti-psychotic drugs. The implication of these findings for social workers who work with the seriously mentally ill are discussed. Alternatives to current pharmacological treatments that are more targeted toward the core physiology of schizophrenia are reviewed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Mental+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Will+the+Treatment+Protocols+for+Schizophrenia+be+Changing+Soon%3F&amp;rft.au=Littrell%2C+Jill+Leslie&amp;rft.aulast=Littrell&amp;rft.aufirst=Jill&amp;rft.date=2014-07-04&amp;rft.volume=12&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=365&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Mental+Health&amp;rft.issn=15332985&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15332985.2014.894487

Integrating Social Work into Palliative Care for Lung Cancer Patients and Families: A Multidimensional Approach

Author: Otis-Green, Shirley1; Sidhu, Rupinder K; Del Ferraro, Catherine; Ferrell, Betty1 Division of Nursing Research & Education, City of Hope National Medical Center, Duarte, CA, USA

Publication info: Journal of Psychosocial Oncology  Vol. 32, Iss. 4,  (July 4, 2014): 431-446.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947940?accountid=14667

Abstract: Lung cancer patients and their family caregivers face a wide range of potentially distressing symptoms across the four domains of quality of life. A multidimensional approach to addressing these complex concerns with early integration of palliative care has proven beneficial. This article highlights opportunities to integrate social work using a comprehensive quality of life model and a composite patient scenario from a large lung cancer educational intervention National Cancer Institute-funded program project grant. Adapted from the source document.

Summarizing the Fifteen Scales of the EORTC QLQ-C30 Questionnaire by Five Aggregate Scales with Two Underlying Dimensions: A Literature Review and an Empirical Study

Author: van der Kloot, Willem A.1; Kobayashi, Kunihiko; Yamaoka, Kazue; Inoue, Kenichi; Nortier, Hans W R; Kaptein, Ad A1 Institute of Psychology, Leiden University, Leiden, The Netherlands

Publication info: Journal of Psychosocial Oncology  Vol. 32, Iss. 4,  (July 4, 2014): 413-430.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947986?accountid=14667

Abstract: The intercorrelations among the 15 scales of the 30-item Core version of the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire suggest that one may combine (1) the physical functioning and role functioning scales, (2) the emotional functioning and cognitive functioning scales, and (3) the nine symptom scales. Together with the global health/quality of life scale and the social functioning scale, five measures remain. Principal component analysis of those five measures, using data from Japanese and Dutch breast and lung cancer patients, yielded two dimensions: (1) generalized health related quality of life and (2) health-independent psychological well-being. The correlations of these dimensions with the Brief Illness Perception Questionnaire and Karnofsky performance substantiated this interpretation. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Summarizing+the+Fifteen+Scales+of+the+EORTC+QLQ-C30+Questionnaire+by+Five+Aggregate+Scales+with+Two+Underlying+Dimensions%3A+A+Literature+Review+and+an+Empirical+Study&amp;rft.au=van+der+Kloot%2C+Willem+A.%3BKobayashi%2C+Kunihiko%3BYamaoka%2C+Kazue%3BInoue%2C+Kenichi%3BNortier%2C+Hans+W+R%3BKaptein%2C+Ad+A&amp;rft.aulast=van+der+Kloot&amp;rft.aufirst=Willem&amp;rft.date=2014-07-04&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=413&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F07347332.2014.917139

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Summarizing+the+Fifteen+Scales+of+the+EORTC+QLQ-C30+Questionnaire+by+Five+Aggregate+Scales+with+Two+Underlying+Dimensions%3A+A+Literature+Review+and+an+Empirical+Study&amp;rft.au=van+der+Kloot%2C+Willem+A.%3BKobayashi%2C+Kunihiko%3BYamaoka%2C+Kazue%3BInoue%2C+Kenichi%3BNortier%2C+Hans+W+R%3BKaptein%2C+Ad+A&amp;rft.aulast=van+der+Kloot&amp;rft.aufirst=Willem&amp;rft.date=2014-07-04&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=413&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F07347332.2014.917139

Is It Helpful to Give Older People with Cancer the Same Chance at Rehabilitation as Older General Medical Patients?

Author: Lethborg, C1; Brown, R; Posenelli, S; Pollerd, L; Wigg, S; Challis, C; Hocking, A; Whitehall, C1 Department of Social Work, St. Vincent's Hospital, Melbourne, Australia

Publication info: Journal of Psychosocial Oncology  Vol. 32, Iss. 4,  (July 4, 2014): 396-412.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947988?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although the complexity of age combined with a cancer diagnosis can result in unmet supportive care needs there are seldom resources to assess or address such needs for older people with cancer (OPWC). The purpose of this project was to trial a service to improve the care for OPWC through (1) an expanded supportive care screening process and (2) capacity building of subacute ambulatory care services (SACS) staff to increase referrals to community-based rehabilitation. Methods/design: Collaboration between allied health (AH) staff at an inner city general hospital with a large cancer service, a cancer specialist hospital, and a SACS service in Melbourne, Australia, developed an AH geriatric screening assessment (GSA) tool. Parallel to this process training was provided to SACS staff in relation to working with OPWC. Although close to one half (44%) of SACS staff who participated in this program (n = 22) had over 6 years' experience, 32% had not worked with OPWC. Prior to training, 81% did not feel confident in their knowledge about working with this cohort. After their training 72% were more confident about normal aging and implications for care of OPWC. Of the 491 patients screened, 80% were older than age 65, however, only 25 resided in the SACS catchment area. More than one third of these did not have clear rehabilitation needs, and the remainder were not referred due to ongoing medical issues. Less than one half of the patients in the catchment area were discussed in a Multi-disciplinary Meeting (MDM) but all were referred to allied health and assessed using the GSA. Although this project did not result in referrals of OPWC to SACS the training program for SACS staff was a success and allied health assessments were improved to include GSA factors. The complexity of care for OPWC was further highlighted through interviews with staff involved with the study. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Is+It+Helpful+to+Give+Older+People+with+Cancer+the+Same+Chance+at+Rehabilitation+as+Older+General+Medical+Patients%3F&amp;rft.au=Lethborg%2C+C%3BBrown%2C+R%3BPosenelli%2C+S%3BPollerd%2C+L%3BWigg%2C+S%3BChallis%2C+C%3BHocking%2C+A%3BWhitehall%2C+C&amp;rft.aulast=Lethborg&amp;rft.aufirst=C&amp;rft.date=2014-07-04&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=396&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F07347332.2014.917141

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Is+It+Helpful+to+Give+Older+People+with+Cancer+the+Same+Chance+at+Rehabilitation+as+Older+General+Medical+Patients%3F&amp;rft.au=Lethborg%2C+C%3BBrown%2C+R%3BPosenelli%2C+S%3BPollerd%2C+L%3BWigg%2C+S%3BChallis%2C+C%3BHocking%2C+A%3BWhitehall%2C+C&amp;rft.aulast=Lethborg&amp;rft.aufirst=C&amp;rft.date=2014-07-04&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=396&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F07347332.2014.917141

Psychiatric Pathology and Suicide Risk in Patients with Cancer

Author: Costantini, Anna1; Pompili, Maurizio; Innamorati, Marco; Zezza, Maria Cristina; Di Carlo, Alessandra; Sher, Leo; Girardi, Paolo1 Psycho-Oncology Unit, Sant'Andrea Hospital, Sapienza University of Rome, Rome, Italy

Publication info: Journal of Psychosocial Oncology  Vol. 32, Iss. 4,  (July 4, 2014): 383-395.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667948196?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aims of the study were to assess sociodemographic and clinical factors associated with suicidal ideation in patients with cancer who required a psycho-oncological support. Among 504 participants, there were 136 (23 men and 113 women) cancer patients who completed psychological assessment when admitted to the Psycho-oncology Outpatient Clinic between 2006 and 2011. Suicidal ideation was assessed by Item 9 of the Brief Symptom Inventory, Hopelessness was assessed by the hopelessness subscale of the Mini-Mental Adjustment to Cancer Scale, and Depression was assessed by the depression subscale of the Hospital and Anxiety Depression Scale. Around 30% of this sample reported affective symptoms and around 20% reported suicidal ideation and hopelessness. Patients who reported suicidal ideation were more hopeless (18.8 +/- 6.7 vs. 15.7 +/- 5.2; t(134) = 2.54; p < 0.05) and reported more depression (11.8 +/- 4.8 vs. 6.8 +/- 4.1; t(134) = 5.30; p < 0.001). It is evident that cancer can result in a strong psychological distress in the patient. It is important, therefore, that cancer patients receive a proper assistance and psychological support and that both the possible presence of depression and suicidal ideation are constantly monitored. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Psychiatric+Pathology+and+Suicide+Risk+in+Patients+with+Cancer&amp;rft.au=Costantini%2C+Anna%3BPompili%2C+Maurizio%3BInnamorati%2C+Marco%3BZezza%2C+Maria+Cristina%3BDi+Carlo%2C+Alessandra%3BSher%2C+Leo%3BGirardi%2C+Paolo&amp;rft.aulast=Costantini&amp;rft.aufirst=Anna&amp;rft.date=2014-07-04&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=383&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F07347332.2014.917136

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Psychiatric+Pathology+and+Suicide+Risk+in+Patients+with+Cancer&amp;rft.au=Costantini%2C+Anna%3BPompili%2C+Maurizio%3BInnamorati%2C+Marco%3BZezza%2C+Maria+Cristina%3BDi+Carlo%2C+Alessandra%3BSher%2C+Leo%3BGirardi%2C+Paolo&amp;rft.aulast=Costantini&amp;rft.aufirst=Anna&amp;rft.date=2014-07-04&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=383&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F07347332.2014.917136

The Impact of Minority Stressors on the Mental and Physical Health of Lesbian, Gay, and Bisexual Youths and Young Adults

Author: Shilo, Guy; Mor, Zohar

Publication info: Health & Social Work  Vol. 39, Iss. 3,  (August 2014): 161-171.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1567041127?accountid=14667

Abstract: Research relating to minority stressors generally explores mental health outcomes, with limited focus on the physical dimension. In addition, minority stress research is conducted mainly in Christian-oriented societies. To address these pitfalls we used Web sampling targeting Israeli participants ages 12 to 30 (N = 952; 28 percent heterosexuals, 78 percent lesbian, gay, and bisexual [LGB] adolescents and young adults) to assess their mental health, physical and sexual risk behaviors, minority stressors, and coping resources. Results indicate that young LGBs had lower levels of mental and physical health than heterosexuals. Among LGB participants, high levels of minority stressors and low levels of coping resources predicted lower levels of mental health, and lower levels of mental health predicted lower levels of physical health. These results emphasize that minority stressors should be recognized as risk factors for poorer mental health, as well as for physical and sexual risk behaviors. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Impact+of+Minority+Stressors+on+the+Mental+and+Physical+Health+of+Lesbian%2C+Gay%2C+and+Bisexual+Youths+and+Young+Adults&amp;rft.au=Shilo%2C+Guy%3BMor%2C+Zohar&amp;rft.aulast=Shilo&amp;rft.aufirst=Guy&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=161&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Factors Related to Sexual Abuse and Forced Sex in a Sample of Women Experiencing Police-involved Intimate Partner Violence

Author: Messing, Jill Theresa; Thaller, Jonel; Bagwell, Meredith

Publication info: Health & Social Work  Vol. 39, Iss. 3,  (August 2014): 181-191.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1567041129?accountid=14667

Abstract: Intimate partner sexual violence (IPSV) is a significant social problem, particularly among women who are concurrently experiencing physical violence in their intimate relationships. This research examined the prevalence and factors associated with IPSV among a sample of women recruited at the scene of police-involved intimate partner violence incidents (N = 432). Within this sample, 43.98 percent of participants reported experiencing IPSV; this includes 17.36 percent who reported sexual abuse and 26.62 percent who reported forced sex. Multinomial logistic regression was used to examine the factors related to sexual abuse and forced sex, controlling for victim and relationship characteristics. Compared with women not reporting IPSV, women who were sexually abused or forced into sexual intercourse were significantly more likely to experience strangulation, feelings of shame, and posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms. Women whose partners had forced sex were more likely to report that they had a child in common with their abusive partner; and that their partner was sexually jealous, had threatened to kill them, had stalked or harassed them, or caused them to have a miscarriage due to abuse. These findings can be used to better inform social work practitioners about the prevalence and nature of IPSV and the associated risk factors, and can assist in routine screening and intervention. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Factors+Related+to+Sexual+Abuse+and+Forced+Sex+in+a+Sample+of+Women+Experiencing+Police-involved+Intimate+Partner+Violence&amp;rft.au=Messing%2C+Jill+Theresa%3BThaller%2C+Jonel%3BBagwell%2C+Meredith&amp;rft.aulast=Messing&amp;rft.aufirst=Jill&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=181&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Factors+Related+to+Sexual+Abuse+and+Forced+Sex+in+a+Sample+of+Women+Experiencing+Police-involved+Intimate+Partner+Violence&amp;rft.au=Messing%2C+Jill+Theresa%3BThaller%2C+Jonel%3BBagwell%2C+Meredith&amp;rft.aulast=Messing&amp;rft.aufirst=Jill&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=181&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

The task of taking care of children: methodological perspectives and empirical implications

Author: Andenaes, Agnes11 Department of Psychology. University of Oslo

Publication info: Child and Family Social Work  Vol. 19, Iss. 3,  (August 2014): 263-271.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660020025?accountid=14667

Abstract: Methods are not neutral instruments but construct the phenomena under investigation and convey meaning about what is important. This paper explores a methodological framework to investigate parental care for children. As part of the results, the following characteristics of how parents take care of their children are presented: continuous responsibility; predictable routines that are adjusted to the child; and interpretations and negotiations about developmental goals. The argument is that methodological approaches that analyse larger temporal units of contextualized practices as presented by the participants themselves open up for more context-sensitive knowledge about the task of taking care of children. Thus, the understanding of the process of development is widened and specified in a way that may be useful for fields of practice where developmental psychology is 'at work'. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+task+of+taking+care+of+children%3A+methodological+perspectives+and+empirical+implications&amp;rft.au=Andenaes%2C+Agnes&amp;rft.aulast=Andenaes&amp;rft.aufirst=Agnes&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=263&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fj.1365-2206.2012.00897.x

Child Psychiatry in the Chinese Setting

Author: Sibeoni, Jordan1; Harf, Aurelie; Huang, Ying; Moro, Marie Rose1 Department of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, Maison de Solenn- Maison des adolescents, Cochin Hospital, AP-HP, INSERM U669, Paris Descartes University, Sorbonne Paris Cite, 97, Bd de Port Royal, 75014, Paris, France jordan.sibeoni@cch.aphp.fr

Publication info: Child and Adolescent Social Work Journal  Vol. 31, Iss. 4,  (August 2014): 329-337.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1680150367?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article introduces the history and social background and describes the present situation of child psychiatry in China. Certain Chinese social, political and cultural issues are explored, as the one-child policy and the Chinese family structure. Numerous currents of thought coexist in Chinese child psychiatry. Four examples of mental health disorders in child and adolescent psychiatry and their treatments in the Chinese public health care system are described (attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, anorexia nervosa, posttraumatic stress disorder and internet addiction). Adapted from the source document.

Grandmother Caregiver-in-Chief Continues the Tradition of African American Families

Author: Gibson, Priscilla A11 University of Minnesota, St Paul, MN, USA pgibson@umn.edu

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 3,  (August 2014): 298-309.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650582?accountid=14667

Abstract: Grandmother caregiving in African American communities is a tradition used across social classes and circumstances of adult children and grandchildren. Yet, in the literature, it is viewed as a strategy used when the well-being of children is in jeopardy, families have low-incomes and limited resources, and parents are experiencing social problems. However, Mrs. Marian Shields Robinson is serving as a grandmother caregiver to the first African American First Family in the White House. This article provides an expanded view on the variations of grandmother caregiving by critically analyzing it and Mrs. Robinson's role to provide social workers with four implications for practice. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Grandmother+Caregiver-in-Chief+Continues+the+Tradition+of+African+American+Families&amp;rft.au=Gibson%2C+Priscilla+A&amp;rft.aulast=Gibson&amp;rft.aufirst=Priscilla&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=298&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913519794

The Subaltern Writes Back: Immigrant Bangladeshi Girls Punctuating the Equilibrium of Ethnic Patriarchy in New York City

Author: Alam, Mohammed Faridul11 New York City College of Technology, City University of New York (CUNY), New York, NY, USA, Family Assessment Program, Division of Youth and Family Justice, New York City Administration for Children's Services, New York, NY, USA falam126@aol.com

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 3,  (August 2014): 340-352.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650595?accountid=14667

Abstract: The study was grounded in the lived experiences of 13 female and 20 male children of Bangladeshi descent in New York City. It explored how the intersection of ethnicity, gender, generation, and migration shaped the distinctive experiences of the girls as they came of age, straddling the native culture and the host culture. By walking a tightrope between intergenerational continuity of normative gender practice, and change, prompted by egalitarian socialization, they foregrounded educational/career trajectories. Unlike the boys, who acquiesced with the status quo despite its equal opportunity disadvantages, they started rewriting the rules of engagement with patriarchy from this new threshold. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+Subaltern+Writes+Back%3A+Immigrant+Bangladeshi+Girls+Punctuating+the+Equilibrium+of+Ethnic+Patriarchy+in+New+York+City&amp;rft.au=Alam%2C+Mohammed+Faridul&amp;rft.aulast=Alam&amp;rft.aufirst=Mohammed&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=340&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913519795

The Controllability in Intimate Relationships Scale: Measuring Control Macro Contexts

Author: Whitaker, M Pippin1; Abell, Neil1 College of Social Work, University of South Carolina, DeSaussure College, Columbia, SC, USA

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 3,  (August 2014): 261-271.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650612?accountid=14667

Abstract: We present the development and validation of a new measure to assess perceptions of community and social contexts (macro contexts) linked to controllability in relationships. The Controllability in Intimate Relationships Scale measures a person's perceived situation regarding power, resources, and independence. This measure is a first step toward assessing links between macro contexts and control in intimate partner violence. Analyses conducted on the sample of 241 college students and community members included analysis of variance, Cronbach's a, standard error of measurement, and exploratory and confirmatory factor analyses. Results showed good reliability and model fit. Implications for research and practice are discussed. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+Controllability+in+Intimate+Relationships+Scale%3A+Measuring+Control+Macro+Contexts&amp;rft.au=Whitaker%2C+M+Pippin%3BAbell%2C+Neil&amp;rft.aulast=Whitaker&amp;rft.aufirst=M&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=261&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913519790

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+Controllability+in+Intimate+Relationships+Scale%3A+Measuring+Control+Macro+Contexts&amp;rft.au=Whitaker%2C+M+Pippin%3BAbell%2C+Neil&amp;rft.aulast=Whitaker&amp;rft.aufirst=M&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=261&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913519790

Empowering Families in Difficult Times: The Women's Economic Stability Initiative

Author: Scheuler, Leslie1; Diouf, Kathleen; Nevels, Eulonda; Hughes, Nicole1 Brown School of Social Work, Washington University in St. Louis, St. Louis, MO, USA lscheuler@wustl.edu

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 3,  (August 2014): 353-367.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650648?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Women's Economic Stability Initiative developed and evaluated a new model to help low-income, single women with children make progress toward economic stability through vocational training/educational attainment (particularly in fields traditionally dominated by men), financial assistance for reliable childcare, transportation, and housing, and life coaching/case management using an empowerment approach. During the first 3 years of the initiative, participants made progress in attaining academic degrees, maintaining employment, experiencing modest increases in income, some success in building assets, and paying down/eliminating credit card debt. The initiative provided the support needed to help women gain greater stability for themselves and their children. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Empowering+Families+in+Difficult+Times%3A+The+Women%27s+Economic+Stability+Initiative&amp;rft.au=Scheuler%2C+Leslie%3BDiouf%2C+Kathleen%3BNevels%2C+Eulonda%3BHughes%2C+Nicole&amp;rft.aulast=Scheuler&amp;rft.aufirst=Leslie&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=353&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109914522624

Exploring Women's Empowerment Through 'Credit-Plus' Microfinance in India

Author: Krenz, Kristin1; Gilbert, Dorie J; Mandayam, Gokul1 Center for Women's and Gender Studies, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX, USA kristinkrenz@gmail.com

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 3,  (August 2014): 310-325.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650721?accountid=14667

Abstract: Transnational feminist discourse has critiqued the pursuit of women's empowerment through international development programs. Empowerment, when reduced to the provision of financial resources and services, is unlikely to lead to wider changes in gender inequality unless programs strategically combine credit with other vital services. We interviewed women participating in a multifaceted empowerment program in Mumbai, India, to explore the potential of the 'Credit-Plus' model to facilitate pathways of individual and collective empowerment. Emergent themes of empowerment were enhanced socioemotional well-being, increased economic assets, and improved household gender equity. Interview responses demonstrate changes in individual, household, and collective agency dynamics. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+Women%27s+Empowerment+Through+%27Credit-Plus%27+Microfinance+in+India&amp;rft.au=Krenz%2C+Kristin%3BGilbert%2C+Dorie+J%3BMandayam%2C+Gokul&amp;rft.aulast=Krenz&amp;rft.aufirst=Kristin&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=310&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913516453

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+Women%27s+Empowerment+Through+%27Credit-Plus%27+Microfinance+in+India&amp;rft.au=Krenz%2C+Kristin%3BGilbert%2C+Dorie+J%3BMandayam%2C+Gokul&amp;rft.aulast=Krenz&amp;rft.aufirst=Kristin&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=310&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913516453

Abortion and Domestic Violence: Women's Decision-Making Process

Author: Cote, Isabelle1; Lapierre, Simon1 School of Social Work, Universite de Montreal, Quebec, Canada icote066@uottawa.ca

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 3,  (August 2014): 285-297.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650766?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article addresses women's experiences of abortion in the context of domestic violence, more specifically the decision-making process and the influence of the perpetrators in their decision. The data were collected through semistructured individual interviews with four Canadian women, aged between 23 and 36 years at the time of the interviews. Overall, the findings suggest that the factors influencing women's decision can be grouped into the following four categories: domestic violence, the women's individual situation, the couple's situation, and external constraints. Implications for policies and practice are discussed. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Abortion+and+Domestic+Violence%3A+Women%27s+Decision-Making+Process&amp;rft.au=Cote%2C+Isabelle%3BLapierre%2C+Simon&amp;rft.aulast=Cote&amp;rft.aufirst=Isabelle&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=285&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913519791

Transforming Stories and Teachings Into Social Work Pedagogies

Author: Ormiston, Naadli Todd11 University of Victoria, Victoria BC, British Columbia, Canada toddo@shaw.ca

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 3,  (August 2014): 368-372.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650774?accountid=14667

Abstract: Indigenous pedagogies involve seeking out various forms of indigenous knowledge and a commitment to learning and teaching our traditions, ceremonies, philosophies and values, land, and languages. This article validates the differing ways in which indigenous people are infusing indigenous pedagogy into social work education. This article introduces two aspects of indigenous pedagogy that needs to be emphasized by indigenous social work educators: (1) mentoring and nurturing student identity and belongingness and (2) land-based education. For those interested in indigenous epistemologies, this article is intended to provide an additional resource to understanding and practicing indigenous pedagogies. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Transforming+Stories+and+Teachings+Into+Social+Work+Pedagogies&amp;rft.au=Ormiston%2C+Naadli+Todd&amp;rft.aulast=Ormiston&amp;rft.aufirst=Naadli&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=368&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109914522630

Navigating the Domestic Violence Protection Law by Vietnamese Immigrant Wives in Taiwan

Author: Tang, Anna Wen-hui1; Wang, Hong-zen1 National Sun Yat-sen University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 3,  (August 2014): 272-284.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650795?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores the structural factors that hinder Vietnamese immigrant wives from escaping domestic violence by applying an institutional ethnography perspective. Taiwan's Domestic Violence Prevention Law requires the government to assign professionals to help abused victims, but the law in action shows that abused Vietnamese wives must go through multiple institutions, which put different structural constraints on them, to reach the goal of escaping domestic violence. Following the structural intersectionality approach, we contend that gender, nationalism, and class structural factors intersectionally impose constraints on immigrant women seeking help from the state. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Navigating+the+Domestic+Violence+Protection+Law+by+Vietnamese+Immigrant+Wives+in+Taiwan&amp;rft.au=Tang%2C+Anna+Wen-hui%3BWang%2C+Hong-zen&amp;rft.aulast=Tang&amp;rft.aufirst=Anna&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=272&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913519792

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Navigating+the+Domestic+Violence+Protection+Law+by+Vietnamese+Immigrant+Wives+in+Taiwan&amp;rft.au=Tang%2C+Anna+Wen-hui%3BWang%2C+Hong-zen&amp;rft.aulast=Tang&amp;rft.aufirst=Anna&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=272&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913519792

Healing Through Movement: The Benefits of Belly Dance for Gendered Victimization

Author: Moe, Angela M11 Department of Sociology, Western Michigan University, Kalamazoo, MI, USA angie.moe@wmich.edu

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 29, Iss. 3,  (August 2014): 326-339.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650797?accountid=14667

Abstract: Perceptions of 'belly dance' are that it is degrading, exploitive, and incongruous to feminism. Curiously, however, the dance is incredibly popular in various parts of the world, including the United States, as a form of recreation and creative expression. This article examines the apparent disconnect between public perception and practitioner standpoint. Findings indicate a strong holistic healing component, particularly in terms of gendered interpersonal victimization, where belly dance seems to hold potential for self-exploration and discovery. Grounded historically, culturally, and empirically, these findings are discussed in terms of their application to social work practice, as it relates to alternative therapies. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Healing+Through+Movement%3A+The+Benefits+of+Belly+Dance+for+Gendered+Victimization&amp;rft.au=Moe%2C+Angela+M&amp;rft.aulast=Moe&amp;rft.aufirst=Angela&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=326&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913516454

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Healing+Through+Movement%3A+The+Benefits+of+Belly+Dance+for+Gendered+Victimization&amp;rft.au=Moe%2C+Angela+M&amp;rft.aulast=Moe&amp;rft.aufirst=Angela&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=326&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109913516454

PREPARING SOCIAL WORKERS FOR ALTERNATIVE DISPUTE RESOLUTION IN CARE AND PROTECTION CASES

Author: Matthias, Carmel R

Publication info: Maatskaplike Werk/Social Work  Vol. 50, Iss. 3,  (August 2014): 421-433.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993207?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Children's Act 38 of 2005 contains provisions enabling utilisation of alternative dispute resolution (ADR) in cases involving children. This article focuses on the specialised training required to prepare social workers to be effective ADR practitioners. By drawing on comparative data, the article demonstrates that it is essential for social workers to receive such training in South Africa. The nature of the training that would be required to empower South African social workers to be effective ADR facilitators in care and protection cases is explored. Proposals for a South African training programme are put forward. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=PREPARING+SOCIAL+WORKERS+FOR+ALTERNATIVE+DISPUTE+RESOLUTION+IN+CARE+AND+PROTECTION+CASES&amp;rft.au=Matthias%2C+Carmel+R&amp;rft.aulast=Matthias&amp;rft.aufirst=Carmel&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=421&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=PREPARING+SOCIAL+WORKERS+FOR+ALTERNATIVE+DISPUTE+RESOLUTION+IN+CARE+AND+PROTECTION+CASES&amp;rft.au=Matthias%2C+Carmel+R&amp;rft.aulast=Matthias&amp;rft.aufirst=Carmel&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=421&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

EXPERIENCES OF SOCIAL EXCLUSION AMONG YOUNG DEAF ADULTS INFLUENCING THEIR BELIEFS AND PERCEPTIONS OF HIV/AIDS

Author: Ismail, Amanda; Henderson, Neil

Publication info: Maatskaplike Werk/Social Work  Vol. 50, Iss. 3,  (August 2014): 434-454.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993650?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper reports on a Master's study whose aim was to capture the beliefs and perceptions of young deaf adults about HIV/AIDS in the Cape Metropole and surrounding areas. The study utilised the explorative, contextual and qualitative descriptive study design. Purposive sampling was implemented and data were collected through focus groups and in-depth interviews. Data were analysed using content analysis. Ethical considerations were adhered to. The main findings of the study indicate that numerous myths and misperceptions about HIV/AIDS prevail among deaf people. This paper advocates for policymakers to include deaf people, particularly sign language users, in HIV-prevention programmes. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=EXPERIENCES+OF+SOCIAL+EXCLUSION+AMONG+YOUNG+DEAF+ADULTS+INFLUENCING+THEIR+BELIEFS+AND+PERCEPTIONS+OF+HIV%2FAIDS&amp;rft.au=Ismail%2C+Amanda%3BHenderson%2C+Neil&amp;rft.aulast=Ismail&amp;rft.aufirst=Amanda&amp;rft.date=2014-08-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=434&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Hospital social workers' assessment processes for children at risk: positions in and contributions to inter-professional teams

Author: Svard, Veronica11 Department of Social Work, Mid Sweden University, Ostersund, Sweden

Publication info: European Journal of Social Work  Vol. 17, Iss. 4,  (August 8, 2014): 508-522.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018794?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores hospital social workers' assessment processes for children at risk within the context of inter-professional teams working in child hospital care in Sweden. Based on qualitative interviews, the study discusses how assessment processes for children at risk can be understood from a professionalism perspective. Three institutionalized norms-juridical, therapeutic, and medical, building on different knowledge systems-are analyzed in relation to the three positions taken by hospital social workers as team members-active, reflective, or passive-leading to different kinds of actions in the assessment processes. The outlined norms and the positions taken involve consequences for the children and their families, but also pose questions for the future professionalization efforts of hospital social work. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Hospital+social+workers%27+assessment+processes+for+children+at+risk%3A+positions+in+and+contributions+to+inter-professional+teams&amp;rft.au=Svard%2C+Veronica&amp;rft.aulast=Svard&amp;rft.aufirst=Veronica&amp;rft.date=2014-08-08&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=508&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13691457&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F13691457.2013.806296

____________________________________________________________

Understanding the longer-term effects of family group conferences

Author: Malmberg-Heimonen, Ira1; Johansen, Sissel1 Department of Social Work, Child Welfare and Social Policy, Faculty of Social Sciences, Social Welfare Research Centre, Oslo and Akershus University College of Applied Sciences, Oslo, Norway

Publication info: European Journal of Social Work  Vol. 17, Iss. 4,  (August 8, 2014): 556-571.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018817?accountid=14667

Abstract: Few studies estimate the longer-term effects of family group conferences (FGCs), as previous research has been mainly qualitative or has focused only on the shorter-term effects of FGCs. This study analyses, using a randomised controlled design, the longer-term effects of adult FGCs in terms of social support, mental health and re-employment. A total of 149 Norwegian longer-term social assistance recipients were randomly assigned to intervention and control groups. Participants were followed up 12 months after baseline. To gain in-depth knowledge of the FGC process, 15 participants were interviewed. Despite high shares of participant satisfaction and significant shorter-term effects, the one-year follow-up identified neutral effects of the intervention. Qualitative interviews demonstrated that lack of reciprocity in social relationships and lack of follow-up were the main reasons for the stagnation of an initially positive FGC process. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Understanding+the+longer-term+effects+of+family+group+conferences&amp;rft.au=Malmberg-Heimonen%2C+Ira%3BJohansen%2C+Sissel&amp;rft.aulast=Malmberg-Heimonen&amp;rft.aufirst=Ira&amp;rft.date=2014-08-08&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=556&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13691457&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F13691457.2013.818528

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Understanding+the+longer-term+effects+of+family+group+conferences&amp;rft.au=Malmberg-Heimonen%2C+Ira%3BJohansen%2C+Sissel&amp;rft.aulast=Malmberg-Heimonen&amp;rft.aufirst=Ira&amp;rft.date=2014-08-08&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=556&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13691457&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F13691457.2013.818528

Activating Adult-Learning Principles Through Small Groups in Preparing Social Work Students to Achieve CSWE Research Competencies

Author: Steinberg, Dominique Moyse1; Vinjamuri, Mohan Krishna1 School for Social Work, Smith College, Northampton, Massachusetts, USA

Publication info: Journal of Teaching in Social Work  Vol. 34, Iss. 4,  (August 8, 2014): 363-383.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018830?accountid=14667

Abstract: The research classroom is a prime venue for socializing master's-level students as evidence-based practitioners. This article identifies an innovative approach to teaching research based on five adult-learning principles and the use of small ongoing groups that, when blended as the signature pedagogy, enable students to successfully actualize the Council on Social Work Education Educational Policy and Accreditation Standards required for professional practice. The article describes and discusses the five adult-learning principles that form the basis of this approach and four types of small-group activities that are used over the yearlong course, concluding with implications for reorganizing the traditional research classroom. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Teaching+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Activating+Adult-Learning+Principles+Through+Small+Groups+in+Preparing+Social+Work+Students+to+Achieve+CSWE+Research+Competencies&amp;rft.au=Steinberg%2C+Dominique+Moyse%3BVinjamuri%2C+Mohan+Krishna&amp;rft.aulast=Steinberg&amp;rft.aufirst=Dominique&amp;rft.date=2014-08-08&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=363&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Teaching+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=08841233&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F08841233.2014.937890

____________________________________________________________

Thinking Spatially: Teaching an Undervalued Practice Skill

Author: Steiner, Sue1; Wagaman, M Alex; Lal, Pravina1 School of Social Work, California State University, Chico, Chico, California, USA

Publication info: Journal of Teaching in Social Work  Vol. 34, Iss. 4,  (August 8, 2014): 427-442.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660019923?accountid=14667

Abstract: Spatial thinking, which is taught and practiced in many of the social sciences, is a skill that is often overlooked in the social work curriculum. Spatial thought increases perception, logic, and organized cognition of goals and therefore holds promise for social work practice. Developing skills in spatial thought offers social workers additional tools for problem solving at all practice levels. Finally, thinking spatially raises awareness of problem-solving techniques in relation to environmental resources, a key aspect of systems theory. Fortunately, spatial thinking can be easily integrated into a variety of social work classes helping students master the skill and understand its importance. This article defines and describes spatial thinking, explores its fit in various areas of the social work curriculum, and discusses ways its use can be encouraged. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Teaching+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Thinking+Spatially%3A+Teaching+an+Undervalued+Practice+Skill&amp;rft.au=Steiner%2C+Sue%3BWagaman%2C+M+Alex%3BLal%2C+Pravina&amp;rft.aulast=Steiner&amp;rft.aufirst=Sue&amp;rft.date=2014-08-08&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=427&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Teaching+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=08841233&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F08841233.2014.933755

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Teaching+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Thinking+Spatially%3A+Teaching+an+Undervalued+Practice+Skill&amp;rft.au=Steiner%2C+Sue%3BWagaman%2C+M+Alex%3BLal%2C+Pravina&amp;rft.aulast=Steiner&amp;rft.aufirst=Sue&amp;rft.date=2014-08-08&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=427&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Teaching+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=08841233&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F08841233.2014.933755

____________________________________________________________

'I've come on this course to learn how to be politically minded': political discourses among students entering a social work programme

Author: Duschinsky, Robbie1; Kirk, Guy1 Social Work & Communities, Northumbria University, Newcastle, UK

Publication info: European Journal of Social Work  Vol. 17, Iss. 4,  (August 8, 2014): 587-599.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660020123?accountid=14667

Abstract: Small-group self-administered interviews were conducted with 80 students entering a social work degree in the UK, asking about their motivations, political engagement and perspectives on equality. Especially as the interviews went on, many students were found to identify structural constraints on agency and express a desire to learn more about the political stakes of social work. However, it was concluded that speakers had to contend with, and by degrees operate upon, a neoliberal discursive terrain. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=%27I%27ve+come+on+this+course+to+learn+how+to+be+politically+minded%27%3A+political+discourses+among+students+entering+a+social+work+programme&amp;rft.au=Duschinsky%2C+Robbie%3BKirk%2C+Guy&amp;rft.aulast=Duschinsky&amp;rft.aufirst=Robbie&amp;rft.date=2014-08-08&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=587&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13691457&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F13691457.2013.829804

____________________________________________________________

Infusing Criminal Justice Content Into the Graduate Social Work Curriculum

Author: Warde, Bryan11 Social Work Program, Lehman College, City University of New York, Bronx, New York, USA

Publication info: Journal of Teaching in Social Work  Vol. 34, Iss. 4,  (August 8, 2014): 413-426.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660020176?accountid=14667

Abstract: Despite the intersection of social work and criminal justice, criminal justice content is only marginally present in social work education. Given that most social work students will at some point in their career work with clients who are directly or collaterally affected by the criminal justice system, this marginal presence is problematic and needs reversing. This article makes the case for graduate social work education programs to consider infusing criminal justice content into their social work curriculum. Supporting this case is a description of an infusion approach and pedagogical strategies for delivering criminal justice content to students. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Teaching+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Infusing+Criminal+Justice+Content+Into+the+Graduate+Social+Work+Curriculum&amp;rft.au=Warde%2C+Bryan&amp;rft.aulast=Warde&amp;rft.aufirst=Bryan&amp;rft.date=2014-08-08&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=413&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Teaching+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=08841233&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F08841233.2014.934946

Safety in the Classroom: Reconsidered

Author: Garran, Ann Marie1; Rasmussen, Brian M1 School of Social Work, University of Connecticut, West Hartford, Connecticut, USA

Publication info: Journal of Teaching in Social Work  Vol. 34, Iss. 4,  (August 8, 2014): 401-412.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660020219?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article challenges the normative and prescriptive constructs of classroom 'safety.' It urges social work educators to reexamine its meaning and the potential differential experience of safety for students from marginalized groups and less privileged social locations. Shifting our conceptual awareness in this sense provides instructors with a more realistic framework to respond proactively, and at times, in the moment, to classroom dynamics. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Teaching+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Safety+in+the+Classroom%3A+Reconsidered&amp;rft.au=Garran%2C+Ann+Marie%3BRasmussen%2C+Brian+M&amp;rft.aulast=Garran&amp;rft.aufirst=Ann&amp;rft.date=2014-08-08&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=401&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Teaching+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=08841233&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F08841233.2014.937517

The Importance of Mentoring Faculty Members of Color in Schools of Social Work

Author: Chadiha, Letha A1; Aranda, Maria P; Biegel, David E; Chang, Ching-Wen1 School of Social Work, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan, USA

Publication info: Journal of Teaching in Social Work  Vol. 34, Iss. 4,  (August 8, 2014): 351-362.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660020476?accountid=14667

Abstract: Mentoring has received little attention in the social work literature. The career advancement needs, and the importance of mentoring faculty members of color, have not been adequately addressed, nor have mentoring strategies. This article includes a review of the literature, a definition of mentoring, benefits of mentoring for mentors and mentees, and discussion of the need and importance of mentoring junior faculty members of color in schools and departments of social work, along with strategies to achieve this goal. Adapted from the source document.

Introduction: Social Work Practice with Asian Populations

Author: Hong, Young Joon

Publication info: Journal of Social Service Research  Vol. 40, Iss. 4,  (August 8, 2014): 381-384.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667943648?accountid=14667

Abstract: Due to the complex mixture of different cultures, countries, races, religions, histories, languages, and economic and political trajectories that forms Asian and Asian American communities (Noble, 2004), social work practitioners may have difficulties understanding these populations as their clients. Furthermore, many matters of concern to Asians and Asian Americans in social work settings have been understudied. Little research has been done, particularly on mental health and elderly issues in Asian populations. Therefore the purpose of this special issue is to further inform social work researchers and practitioners alike about the state of the literature and intervention method when working with Asians and Asian Americans. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Service+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Introduction%3A+Social+Work+Practice+with+Asian+Populations&amp;rft.au=Hong%2C+Young+Joon&amp;rft.aulast=Hong&amp;rft.aufirst=Young&amp;rft.date=2014-08-08&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=381&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Service+Research&amp;rft.issn=01488376&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01488376.2014.923683

Functional Independence of Community-Dwelling Older Adults in China and South Korea

Author: Lee, Othelia Eun-Kyoung; Xu, Qingwen; Lee, Jungui

Publication info: Journal of Social Service Research  Vol. 40, Iss. 4,  (August 8, 2014): 440-453.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667946749?accountid=14667

Abstract: Population aging is occurring at an unprecedented pace in China and South Korea. This study intended to identify and compare factors associated with older adults' functional status in China and South Korea using data from 2 national surveys. The study sample consisted of adults aged 65 to 79 years old drawn from the Chinese Longitudinal Healthy Longevity Survey (2005; n = 4,898) and the Korean Longitudinal Study on Aging (2006; n = 4,152). The outcome variable, functional status, was defined as dependence in self-care tasks. Stepwise multiple regression analysis was used to assess the explanatory contributions of sociodemographics, health conditions, and health behaviors and activities to functional status. These Asian older adults shared certain commonalities in maintaining functional independence in their communities, and absence of diseases and higher cognition were associated with functional independence in both countries. Rural residence and outdoor activity were significant for Chinese older adults; for their South Korean peers, gender, employment status, drinking, and exercise were important. This study adds to a slowly growing body of knowledge of ways to improve the functional independence of community-dwelling older persons in these 2 Asian countries and beyond. More research is needed to identify cross-cultural and/or cross-country differences. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Service+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Functional+Independence+of+Community-Dwelling+Older+Adults+in+China+and+South+Korea&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Othelia+Eun-Kyoung%3BXu%2C+Qingwen%3BLee%2C+Jungui&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Othelia&amp;rft.date=2014-08-08&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=440&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Service+Research&amp;rft.issn=01488376&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01488376.2014.905165

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Service+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Functional+Independence+of+Community-Dwelling+Older+Adults+in+China+and+South+Korea&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Othelia+Eun-Kyoung%3BXu%2C+Qingwen%3BLee%2C+Jungui&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Othelia&amp;rft.date=2014-08-08&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=440&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Service+Research&amp;rft.issn=01488376&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01488376.2014.905165

Factors Associated With Productive Engagement Among Older South Koreans

Author: Lee, Othelia Eun-Kyoung; Lee, Jungui

Publication info: Journal of Social Service Research  Vol. 40, Iss. 4,  (August 8, 2014): 454-467.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947343?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although positive relationships among health, types of activities, and productive aging have been documented in Western industrial nations, little attention has been paid to rapidly developing countries. This study examined unique factors using national South Korean data. Community-dwelling adults aged 55 years and older (n = 6,688) were drawn from Wave II of the Korean Longitudinal Study on Aging. Binary logistic regression analysis was conducted to identify the main and interaction effects related to labor force participation (LFP) and lifelong-learning participation (LLP). Whereas one third (34.4%) of the respondents were involved in LFP, LLP was extremely low (6.8%). Health and socioeconomic status were significant in conducting LFP and LLP. Depression and cognition contributed to LFP but not LLP. Older men who reported higher levels of depression were less likely to engage in LLP than were their female peers. For female respondents, the social activities of exercise and alumni meetings contributed to the likelihood of LLP. Given the lower socioeconomic characteristics and low participation in lifelong learning, it is essential to establish financial incentives to encourage activity participation and develop programs to promote productive aging in South Korea. Future studies should consider the impact of environments and social policy on productive engagement. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Service+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Factors+Associated+With+Productive+Engagement+Among+Older+South+Koreans&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Othelia+Eun-Kyoung%3BLee%2C+Jungui&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Othelia&amp;rft.date=2014-08-08&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=454&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Service+Research&amp;rft.issn=01488376&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01488376.2014.894369

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Service+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Factors+Associated+With+Productive+Engagement+Among+Older+South+Koreans&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Othelia+Eun-Kyoung%3BLee%2C+Jungui&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Othelia&amp;rft.date=2014-08-08&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=454&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Service+Research&amp;rft.issn=01488376&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01488376.2014.894369
